content:
Posted: May 14, 2015
Early Access Review
								(9/09/2015) - http://steamcommunity.com/id/tgchan/recommended/310560/Hello everyone,I will keep updating this review with new thoughts and incoming updates. First of all, I AM ALL TO THE PAIN SIM DRIVER! (I was so afraid to buy this game because of ARCADISH style of previous ones - FEAR NOT and buy now !) Few years of Richard Burns Rally (raw, rsrbr, rbr-world), iRacing, Live for Speed etc. I will write some more in free time - I have to rally some more now!THE GOOD:+ soft-lock is a great feauture~! (you don't have to set rotation of your wheel for each car, you put it on max and the game will do the rest, fixing it to a current driven car)+ Rally Cross mode is plenty of fun. The cars feel much better than the ones from rally mode, a bit too slippery though, it feels like driving on ice most of the time+ dashcam is way to go, forget the cockpit view if you strive for the maximum realism. It looks and feels amazing~! I just wish more cars would have shift-light and gear inf box located higher so we could see them in this view+ 306 Maxi + German special stages on tarmac are so much fun+ driving on a rim (without a tyre) is not fun :)+ with higher difficulty, the weather conditions get worse (night, snow, rain etc.) Unfortunately, only your visibility is affected... the handling stays the same...+ I can't get enough of how rain looks like... simply amazing+ WRC Ford Fiesta handles beautifully on Welsh stages!+ night + heavy rain = heaven!+ amazing lighting work; it looks so incredible when you are driving through shaded areas and the bright sun rays are falling into your cockpit+ if you hold the handbrake with RWD cars without clutch you can stall them, yea!+ your gears can pop out, if you have damaged gearbox!!!+ daily, weekly and monthly online events where you can't restart! YEA!!!+ sounds!+ graphics (about which, I really don't care - but it looks amazing)+ overall pleasure from rallying!+ I expected much worse+ water-splash is so sick!!!+ car repairs+ sense of speed+ it is already much better than RBR!!! Can you believe it!? No?! Me too! BUT IT IS - trust me!+ I can't stop rallying already and I am driving the slowest car~! + great animations of cockpit, you can see your feet working on gas, brake and clutch pedals+ logitech g27 @ 540* works like a charm!+ SS (special stages) look amazing!THE BAD:- NOT EVEN CLOSE TO RICHARD BURN'S RALLY! ARCADY AS F*CK... It is far far away from being a simulator... It is plenty of fun but I don't think it will even come close to RBR...- zero respect for the speed... you can drive 100km/h, hit a tree and still drive without any consequence... PATHETIC!- [PARTIALLY FIXED - all surfaces feel weird] during the rain, you can't tell the difference between wet and dry surface... ARCADE BS!- zero respect for Monte Carlo stages... too much grip... too easy... ARCADE BS!- you can barely slide the car unless you use a handbrake...- [FIXED - clutch override option added] there is no MANUAL SEQUENTIAL GEARBOX + MANUAL CLUTCH... which is real WRC car setup- the power of WRC MINI on tarmac is some kind of a bad joke...- you start rolling after a great crash and the game resets you on the road... stop with this arcade BS!- terrible ARCADE DAMAGE SYSTEM! You can literally bounce back from walls... - bring the deadly one from RBR!!! No mercy for arcade noobs ! - when you fell out of a road, it takes one button to recover... WTF!? It should be at least 30sec of penalty!THE UGLY:~ [PARTIALLY FIXED... still not fair]=[all cars except for WRC have now delay when using sequential gearbox, very good idea] people driving with full manual setups and zero assists ( h-pattern + manual clutch = it is so much HARDER ) should not be thrown into bag with other drivers using different easier setups.~ the cars slow down way too fast when you are not accelerating!~ not enough stages in my opinion. Even though the location are very nice, they get boring rather quickly...~ [PARTIALLY FIXED... still feels slugish]=[latest ffb patch made it so detailed, I don't know if I should rally or admire how nice it is! Now you read the car behaviour instead of fighting with a wheel. Feels amazing! The car is ALIVE!!!] FFB feels like I am driving every car without a power steering, I constantly have to fight with my wheel... after 13h+ of rallying it is so bloody annoying!~ [FIXED]=[latest ffb patch made it so detailed, I don't know if I should rally or admire how nice it is! Now you read the car behaviour instead of fighting with a wheel. Feels amazing! The car is ALIVE!!!] definitely needs more details in handling (although some icy parts of the road were amazing and they have sent me straight into a wall)~ how can you not let us change different tyres for different surfaces!? It is rally FFS!~ [FIXED]=[latest ffb patch made it so detailed, I don't know if I should rally or admire how nice it is! Now you read the car behaviour instead of fighting with a wheel. Feels amazing! The car is ALIVE!!!] FFB needs to be much more detailed, it feels very sluggish at the moment - still nice though~ [PARTIALLY FIXED... the gears still pop out randomly]=[they pop out now only when gearbox is damaged or when you have not pressed clutch all the way down during a gear change] gears from my H-pattern pop out from time to time; not sure if bug or simulator thingy* After more than 63 hrs on record of rallying in Dirt Rally, I have found myself missing the real professional sim... and started racing in iRacing again, even though I do not like track racing. This game is really good, and plenty of fun, but it is as close of being a simulator as Counter-Strike is... It will never be a sim, everyone with a little piece of working brain, can see where this is heading... Do I still have a hope for it to become one? No, not anymore. This is nothing more but a good arcade rally game. If they will keep advertising this as a sim, I will change my review drastically, they do not deserve this word SIMULATOR, describing this title!** After 67 hrs on record, I am too irritated with stiff handling and almost none existent weight balance to continue... As I said before, it is only an arcade game and they have no idea about simulations... I want to punch them in the face for talking about simulating a drop in power, on high elevated special stages, when they let you hit a wall at the maximum speed without any consequence... This is not the biggest problem though, you are not taking pleasure from hitting walls, right? Rally is all about the skilfull handling of the car, the way you do it, you balance the weight of the car. Unfortunately, you can't feel it, in this game at all. The physics feel off, cars are too stiff, unresponsive, underpowered and god knows what else... Even the sound of the cars became dull and boring after a while... Those are rally cars god damn it! Let them sound like monsters!Now, I can clearly say that RBR is still no. 1, such a shame...EDIT: After coming back from a month or so break, game feels amazing again. The RallyCross is fun and the cars actually feel like the WRC should have... It is a great game... I am just angry because I know it can be the best rally simulator ever created, I just hate the idea that they are trying to please both; arcade turds and sim freaks like myself... Unfortunately because of this, the games falls somewhere in between... Too hard for total arcade noobs, and too arcady for a real simulator... What a shame...More incoming soon!Thanks for reading--tgchan.com

content:
Posted: August 22, 2015
Early Access Review
								The mechanics in this game feel excellent, it runs smoothly, and it feels like an accurate simulation of actual driving.I play full manual with H-shifter & clutch on a Logitech G27 wheel (which the game picked up and configured the settings for perfectly) and the force feedback and wheel return is pretty much perfect. They seem to be adding new content fairly regularly, all of which so far has been of a very high quality.It's early access so there's a couple of small bugs here and there as of writing this review which I'm sure will get fixed, but nothing major. Alt tabbing the game means it switches to windowed mode which is annoying, and starting without launch control sometimes results in a jumped start even though I'm in neutral with the handbrake on. Otherwise I haven't noticed any other bugs and it hasn't crashed once.This is the best realistic driving game around right now, and one of the only games I would recommend buying in early access. They are doing early access right.

content:
Posted: May 2, 2015
Early Access Review
								I bought this on prerelease with a little concern given how hit or miss codemasters can be (Dirt Showdown anyone?) and didn't want a racing game aimed at the console crowd where a gamepad plays better than a wheel after all the assists are added. This game amazes with great physics, beautiful graphics, and a challenging set of race stages. It might be too sim-like and complicated for children with the extensive car set-ups and difficult runs, but the cars drive so realistically with a wheel (g27 here) it is incredibly immersive and provides a compelling racing experience. The cons are that it is still pre-release at this time and while the online challenges provide a sort of multiplayer, it still doesn't have true multiplayer races which I will be disappointed if they don't add eventually. And I'll be annoyed if this is all you get and the additional promised content will be DLC that you have to purchase after the "official" release of the game. Nevertheless, for the prerelease cost it is an awesome game that is worth buying if you like driving games with realistic physics and great graphics. My feeling is that the work Codemasters put into the physics paid off and they have a winner in this genre.

content:
Posted: May 15, 2016
												This game is punishing, and I adore it. Nothing like any of the previous DiRT titles where you can just mash down the gas and steer for dear life although fun not realistic.  I found out very quick that you have to finely tune your vehicle and finesse it through every track, alot of skill to build in this game. At the time of this review I'm only sitting at around 15hrs or so but from what I can see there are a lot of tracks to race on and vehicles to unlock or should I say purchase.  Again it's nothing like any of the previous DiRT titles, it's an actual simulation now instead of an arcade game.  It's punishing, I'll say it again..IT'S PUNISHING. Now you get a crew chief and get to hire and upgrade mechanics, in between stages you can repair your car.  The graphics are beautiful and the sound is great.  To be honest I was shocked when I first started playing, I couldn't do anything or keep my car on the road because I was so used to how the old DiRT titles played.  I stepped back took a deep breath and began to start respecting the game for what it had evolved into, an effing simulation.  Once I learned I had to tweak my car settings for every single track and gave the game respect I started picking it up and learning to drive again.  In the old DiRT series you really didn't have to make serious adjustments for most tracks anyways, in this game you really need to...or you will fail.  Also I read some other reviews about people playing with a M&K..not going to happen...you need a controller by default.  This game actually makes me want to go out and invest into a wheel and pedals, I have never ever considered that until now.  I'm about to take my nerd level up a notch. I played DiRT 2 the most even after DiRT 3 was released since I was so ashamed of DiRT 3 and all of the Gymkhana whatever stuff they forced into a series of races.  Now that we are back to DiRT lets keep it here please, this game has redeemed the series and for that I am truly grateful.  The game just feels and looks and sounds so good, and there are a lot more customizable options now to your cars, I don't want to spoil it but you have to "unlock" the good customization options. You are going to need them, the more you drive a car the more your team becomes familiar and the more unlocks for your customization abilities for that particular car you are granted.  The nice thing is all of the liveries are already unlocked giving you a little bit of flavor right off the bat, but the new customization replaces you being able to unlock paint jobs. The game feels balanced, the physics are very punishing and realistic and you will grow to respect the track and your car very quickly.  I have not found a track I dislike yet, they are modeled so well and the physics of each track are so amazing and..whats the word...brutal.  One other thing about the DiRT series I always loved was the replays, and they are just as amazing now as they always were.  There is no more rewind your mistakes, now its "reset" your car with a time penalty unless you can drive out of your mistake quicker than resetting your car.  You can resart the race but you will lose a specific amount of credits that are given to you each race as a reward for not using the restart feature. Eventually using the restart enough times in one race will render you with zero bonus credits but they will not affect your original credits you will earn for finishing the race.  Very well done on Codemasters part, they are very balanced on punishing you as a driver without robbing you. ;) They did a good job with this game this time around folks, you can plunge into career mode "like me" or go test drive any car on any track on custom championship.  In career mode they don't necessarily throttle you to go a certain way, it's basically up to you and how you spend your hard earned credits towards vehicles in order to access certain tracks and races.  Codemasters deserve a nice little pat on the back, job well done. If you were or are a rally or DiRT fan and want to kick it up a notch or two buy this game, you won't regret it.  It's punishing and beautiful and lots and lots of replay value.

number of helpful: 16 of 22 people (73%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 9, 2015
												I bought an old Microsoft Sidewinder Force 2 USB directional force feedback joystick used on eBay after playing Dirt 3 and loving the game, but feeling like the controls were way too similar to old console games from the 90s back before analog sticks came around.Back in the late 90s, I started a computer store and I used to sell the Logitech brand of directional force feedback wheels and sticks.  Logitech had the best hardware ever brought to the consumer market when it came to the sticks and the cables and the motors.  It made a decent racing/flying game an absolutely riviting experience.  To give an idea of why directional force feedback matters, try getting into a go-kart at a local kart racing place.  Just rent a kart and go around the track.  That wheel will fight you around every turn, and it makes the driver/road connection a real wrestling match.  This is also what it is like racing a full sized vehicle off road, on gravel, or on dirt.  When you push a vehicle to the limits of traction and beyond, that wheel becomes quite a bear to content with but it also gives you feedback about what the vehicle is doing that is less obvious otherwise.So feedback like this makes a racing experience more real.  Cool.  In addition, the tiny little sticks that most consoles use (like the 360 controller) don't have the fine degree of control that something like racing needs.  The tiny sticks are great when it comes to analog direction, but not so great when it comes to distance between center and fully pressed in a given direction.  This isn't important for all games, but the shortcoming becomes obvious in situations like racing.I play games sitting on the couch, with a projector screen in my living room connected to my PC.  This means a wheel and pedals would be quite cumbersome, because I have no desk to clamp such a monster to.  My experience with wheels is that they are often less precise than a large joystick, and certainly less precise than an actual hydraulic/cable driven steering wheel from a car or kart.All this is why I bought this joystick.  I bought such an old one because they don't make large, directional force feedback analog sticks like this anymore as near as I can tell, the market trends just aren't pushing them.  This old stick requires no drivers in Windows 7 x64, so it really is plug and play.  The old Logitech stick I used to own/sell is technically superior, but it isn't compatible with newer flavors of Windows so it isn't an option anymore.As to the experience, I actually bought Dirt Rally after having some difficulty setting it up with Dirt 3, seeing that Dirt Rally just came out, and reading an interview that says they added analog stick support to the default controller profiles set up for Dirt Rally.  I did get joystick support and directional feedback working with Dirt 3, but it just feels wrong, and it needs to be tuned in some manner because it will literlally throw me off the road even when I have the force dialed back to a mere 10% in the game.  The force reduction doesn't seem to work and the motors are strong enough to literally muscle you off the road, if the game/stick aren't tuned or tunable to work well together.I did have to go in and set the stick and the throttle (built into the stick) as needed so Dirt Rally knew what to do with it but once I did, the motors in the stick snapped to life and the stick was suddenly ready to go (it sits in a relaxed state with the stick lounging to the side until a game talks to it).I jumped into the first track, with the first car.  WOW!  Not only did it bring back memories of playing on my old analog stick and driving racing games like Need for Speed or Star Wars Pod Racing, even better, it reminded me of getting behind the wheel of an actual vehicle and carefully driving around mountain roads as I get a feel for how far I can safely push the vehicle.  I wasn't fast.  I wasn't a speed demon.  It felt like driving a real vehicle.  It wasn't relaxing, it was edge of your seat stuff!  I nearly felt like I had left my house, and had an adventure as I get a feel for gravel roads, as the feedback goes from pushing against you gently, to pushing harder, to going slack when you slingshot past a spot and know if your angle of entry wasn't good you are in trouble because the steering went slack due to a sudden and temporary complete lack of traction.This game isn't flashy.It isn't about eye candy.Tracks take longer, like real driving does.This is the game that gets you into racing.This is the game that gets you into racing games.This game is the reason you get better controllers.Kudos, and thanks for getting me back into racing, and giving me a reason to get into force feedback that is more than mere rumbles!

content:
Posted: October 2, 2016
If you like rallying, driving or a challenge, buy DiRT Rally.If you've ever wondered how rally drivers control their cars in the amazing way in which they do, well DiRT Rally will give you some idea.Other track based racing sims I have are very good, but for me DiRT Rally provides the best overall driving experience.  The cars feel alive!    Spend a bit of time getting it to feel right for you and do a little research about ffb settings and mods.Don't expect to jump in a car and to be quick immediately.  This is a sim.  It will take time to learn and master it, but you will have fun while you are doing so.  With over 280 hours in DiRT Rally I am still learning, and still getting quicker!Finally DRIVE SLOWER TO GO FASTER  You will have heard this before.  It sounds silly, but its true.  Don't drive on the limit and on the edge of crashing at every bend and you will be amazed at your stage times.  The WRC drivers talk about "getting into a rhythm."  When you get into that rhythm you will understand what they mean.

Early Access Review
								It's good, feels updated, give you goosebumps... What more could you want if you like rally? (the compleated game no doubt) My only problem with this game is its still plagued with Codemaster things mainly with the car modeling, brakes that glow red hot for only a second, damage from Dirt Showdown days. Not very new or fresh.edit: The tracks need much more work, the roads are pointy and blotchy. Not very natural, but this is early work. I'm starting to think Dirt Rally isn't new, the car modeling annoys me far too much. Please give the cars some soul, some mass, better visual physics, nerd stuff like traction blobs and brake temp. It currently feels fake :/edit2:The water effects is fantastic, tracks are coming on well yet the skybox is a little ugly. Lost my left back tier on a new finnish stage, sparks constantly. Another rant about car realisum wouldnt help this review but with Project Cars 2 looking as if it may introduce rally CM needs to pick up the pace if they want to keep the crown of best PC rally game.Still, the game gets my heart pounding. Darting around corners then shooting off into intense speeds over rough roads, if you do that well for most of the stage! gotta love it!

												- Started game- Played Monte Carlo descent (snowy). - Too fast into deceptive corner, car totaled- Restart- Too fast, totaled- Restart- Too fast, totaled- Restart- Too fast, totaled- Give up, uninstall game- Reinstall game because why not- Played Monte Carlo descent (snowy)- Too fast, totaled10/10 would total my car again.EDIT: A clarification, for those who feel that the above is unhelpful or "not a real review":I heartily recommend this game because I still wanted to play it, even after failing so hard. I still do. Fail, that is. Yet I keep playing - and improving. Dirt Rally is perhaps the most challenging and rewarding car game I have ever played (and the list that started with Sega Rally 2 has grown quite long). It is fast-paced and unforgiving.In the career mode you have the added complexity of managing your crew, which adds both an interesting tactical flavour as well as a sorely needed input _other_ than your driving skills. This pleases some and annoys some. But the feature is solid.You get a ton of great tracks, a heap of great cars, and hours of good fun. What more do you want?

number of helpful: 8 of 8 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 12, 2015
Early Access Review
								Well I'm gonna have to relearn how to rally because D3 and DR are two totally different monkeys. Dirt 3 was about a collection of cars you had all the access in the world to, and increasing driver level unlocked new cars. DR took the classic route of "if you want it, you gotta earn it!" buy unlocking them with in game currency earned from races. But this game is so far beyond just that simple principal of drive>earn>buy. You have to hire a pit crew who maintain and tune your ride, pay for repairs, keep the crew happy, it gives an authentic feel of running a rally team outside of "this is my car, there are many like it...". And winning makes more money yes, but winning takes REAL work! The cars in this game handle nothing like they did in D3, I've driven my poopy personal IRL car down a dirt road and I have to be just as careful in this game as driving IRL. Crashes ruin your runs, and you get no rewind system. The ONLY assist in this game is your co-pilot, and you have to focus on the road, and what he's feeding you and misinterpreting what he says or not even listening can lead to your car getting wrecked. And the damage system in this game is brutal! I lost a tire mid-race and had to either chug on without it, or stop, and add a few minutes to my stage time replacing it. YES. YOU REPAIR YOUR CAR MID STAGE. And this eats time, which affects your position, which affects your earnings. This game will teach you a whole new respect for the rally world, and that's not a bad thing.If Collin McRae were still here, he would own a hundred copies of this game and he would be so proud of the legacy he left the gaming world.

content:
Posted: January 13
												I was never a big fan of racing games. Back in the day I loved Burnout 3 but it wasn't until Burnout Paradise when I really started loving racing games. After that, it took me years to get back into racing games. GRID 2 and Dirt 3 made me love the genre but both of those are really arcade. Not long after beating Dirt 3 I bought Dirt Rally.Most racing games trick you into thinking that you: 1) Can drive a car in the game really really well and 2) you're actually doing well in it. Dirt Rally does neither of those things. You can immediately tell when you're doing well and when you're not. The feeling of road is insane and will surprise people who aren't used to simulators (and even those who play games like Gran Turismo that are closer to simulation than most racing/rally games out there).In short, the game feels really good. I get instant feedback from doing well. It's so different from most other games I've played. Going back to other racing or rally games might be hard after Dirt Rally.The only real criticism I have is about the variety of tracks. Six events with 12 different stages per event is great and will take you quite a while to master but they totally could have released more events as a DLC and I would have bought that. I still recommend this game very much and I can say it's the best game I found during 2016.

number of helpful: 33 of 55 people (60%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 24, 2016
												After nearly 100 hours in, I figured it was time to throw my two cents into the bucket for DiRT Rally.  The good:-Driving in DiRT Rally does what no other DiRT game has been able to accomplish:  make you feel like you're about to have a MASSIVE accident.  The stages are all real, and some quick searches on the internet will show you that the tree you just crashed into does actually exist, and the rock that sent you for a wild cartwheel has probably claimed a few egos as well.  While DiRT 3 had some of the best multiplayer modes to come out of the series, DiRT Rally fills the gap that has always existed:  Rally.  Not since the days of Richard Burns Rally has a game been able to make me think "I'm about to destroy this car" yet find a way to make me keep my foot down.  -The visuals for this game are part of what gives you the feeling of excitement.  To me, graphics mean nothing in terms of how good a game is, but small things placed along rally stages such as little bushes, rocks, ditches, and even the high-density forests really do produce an exhilarating feeling as you roar through the stages.The bad:-The first, and probably the most jarring, thing that people notice is the lack of content.  Yes, there are (as of now) six different Rallies: Wales, Germany, Sweden, Finland, Monte Carlo, and Greece, however each rally is only two long stages of 15km+, with other stages consisting of half-runs through those stages.  One long stage is run in two directions, then each half is run in either direction, producing 6 stages for each long stage, thus 12 stages possible for each Rally. Fantastic, at first, and even goes so far as being challenging you to go faster as you learn the stages.  However, after a while the stages just become repetitive, and it's no longer new challenges.  You're either fast through the stage or you aren't, and the game begins to lose its luster.  The same goes for the other two modes:  Rallycross and Hillclimb.  So far, only three Rallycross tracks exist, with multiple layouts for each, while Hillclimb only has Pikes Peak, and that can be split into minor sections to add some substance to a rather thin environment. -There are a lot of cars, especially for a Rally game.  However, eagle-eyed players will be quick to note that specific cars will always outrun other cars, regardless of the situation.  For instance, the DiRT Rally forums are quick to point out that the Ford Fiesta is nearly impossible to beat on the Lydden Hill RX, the Peugeot is the king of Sweden's RX, and Norway's is a toss between the two.  As a result, RX multiplayer matches are full of Fords and Peugeots, with the other cars getting little love.  It also seems that there's no interest in addressing the issue.-Small bugs run rampant, and can ruin the game for some.  One major bug is the "exhaust" bug, which can turn a broken, worn-out wreck into a rocket ship.  Another, a little-known mod that may be correcting the variable surface built into the game, providing optimal conditions to those who use it, while others may be left with a worn-out and slick stage.  Currently, there is a popular topic on the forums about whether or not to completely wipe and reset the leaderboards because of it.-More issues, such as dodgy pace notes, fragile tires, shortcuts in the RX tracks, and a possible AI time bug exist, yet don't seem to be getting addressed.Conclusion:If you're a major rally nerd like I am, you'll love the feel this game provides.  Eventually though, everyone will inevitably grow weary of running the same stages over and over through Career mode.  Luckily there are Daily, Weekly, and Monthly modes to compete against the world, and see how you stack up against the human opponents.  A fantastic feature, but without pacing yourself, you could be left with nothing to do for a good portion of the week.  Despite that, I still love the game and play it almost every day, but I always wind up feeling disappointed and wishing there was that little extra something to keep me hooked.

content:
Posted: December 7, 2015
												In one word: 'Dirt!'10/10 Best Rally simulation ever built! Would rip wheels from Mini Cooper with 12km of stage left again!!!This game truly represents a back to basics hardcore experience that places you in the front seat and incontrol of a rally team; where you take this team is entirely left to you from car purchases, to upgrades, the engineers performing this upgrades, graphs galore and other slight car attenuations to match the race car to your needs!This game brings racing simulation for the off road motorsports fan into a new generation, its doesn't require small crowd shiny things such as short tracks, big name narration or more recent additions such as gymkhana and drift... Why? Because all you need is some DiRT (And Ice, Snow, mirror deep Mud to name a few) to Rally on, at the edge of your seat for a white knuckle expereince attempting to hold your car onto the track... so what if 3 of its 4 tires are down and flat, with only 1 tire still up... it doesn't matter as it's just bounced off with your wheel down the embankment! (Who knew you could rip the wheels of a Mini Cooper) The game challenges you to rethink the tactics we've grown used to and that is done so simply its beautiful and it will leave you hanging for more after some short stage recovery. The stages are incredibly intense!This game changes what you know, what we know about Rally games and challenges you to push past its clasp of simulation as it removes the best DiRT Rally games into arcade bins as it creates new standards.Great physics, awesome sound effects, wicked cockpit simulations it's as real as you get and the best bit... No micro transactions... once you buy this game its yours, all of its content and its ongoing updates by the developers that listen to their community! Codemaster you've outdone yourself!!!Drive safe!

number of helpful: 11 of 14 people (79%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 29, 2015
												Edit: FULL RELEASE (short 'n' sweet review).Utterly brilliant package, can't fault it really. My below EA impressions summarise the feel and flow of the game well enough so I don't want to repeat myself.Really impressed with the sheer amount of content for the price too, lots of different cars and locations on offer. Codies back at their absolute best!10/10, cracking game. Best virtual driving experience I've had in years.--------------------------------------------------------------------------------FIRST IMPRESSIONS:Disclaimer... I would hardly call myself an expert but I've been driving things fast since I could reach a steering wheel. Mostly karts, with the odd single-seater and tin-top hoon.+Handling: This thing is hard to master, and I ♥♥♥♥ing love it. The handbrake is my new best friend. I've genuinely not had this much fun with virtual driving in a long time, it's just so involving and physical. It's easy to get going at a somewhat competent pace, but to effectively carry speed you need to go full Finland. Pretty much the closest I've personally felt a game has come to a true driving 'experience' anyway.+Presentation: Slick as ♥♥♥♥, functional, tidy. Does what you want it to fast, and it's very easy to navigate. I love the Colin McRae 2.0-style car outlines, and the doodle pace note icons. It feels like a true-to-heart, wonderfully British rally experience. Awesome stuff.+Stages: Perfect in length, and there's already enough variety in there to keep me busy for a while. They're just long and different enough to keep me on my toes, but not so much that I can't pick it up and start zoning out from pace notes after a few attempts. I hate being overly attentive to them anyway.+Cars: I was surprised by the decent selection we have to kick off with considering the price, good stuff. Seems like a no-messing attempt to get the best rally vehicles possible so that's fine by me. I like how it's split into decades too, nice sense of progression (not just with age but speed!).+Sound/Graphics: I've seen a lot of praise for the former but honestly, both of these seem a minor at best improvement over the stellar Dirt 3. Not a bad thing, I've just not been blown away visually as yet. It's nice and clean though, does what it needs to do. I like the co-driver voice, sounds like a top bloke.ISSUES SO FAR:- FFB can feel a little muted at times.- DFGT wheel seems to not be recognised every now and again, and the resultant pause messes with the steering lock / overall FFB feel. Restarting sorts it.- All audio drops out if I try to play with the 60's Lancia. No idea why.OVERALL:Whether you're an old-school Codies fan or mildly interested in the rally genre, you owe it to yourself to give this a shot. Seriously, expecially for the price, it's ♥♥♥♥ing good.

content:
Posted: March 13, 2016
												Hands down one of the best driving games I have ever had the pleasure of owning. Would I recommend this to you? If you're looking for a challenging driving experience, I would say go for it.The game speaks for itself in a lot of ways. It doesn't hold your hand. The only way you're going to get a podium finish in this game is if you fight for it. But the satisfaction of finally getting there is part of what makes this game so great.I've never focused more in a video game than I have in DiRT Rally. Whether it's in the lush countryside of Germany or the steep rocky trails of Greece, they all have one thing in common; the courses are beautiful. The level of detail in this game is astonishingly well done. The courses presented are true to life and do an excellent job of capturing the scenery. I've found myself slowing down a few times just to admire the view. Whether that view is of the landscape or the car I'm driving, it's always a treat.This game has a lot more to offer than just good visuals. With 39 cars available, ranging from the 60s to modern, there is something here for everyone (personally I can't get enough of the 95' Impreza). While all the cars aren't terribly different from one another, at least not in the same category, they each have their own little personality that can make you love them or hate them.Alongside the career mode that you can progress through, there are also daily, weekly, and monthly leaderboard challenges. These really help the longevity of the game since it's literally infinite challenges. You can also just create your own tournaments or do quick runs on a chosen course(s). If there's one thing I can say that disappointed me with DiRT Rally, it's the number of courses. After you spend many hours with the game, you start to learn locations by heart. Suddenly your co-driver becomes more of a nuisance than a valuable guide. It loses a little of its luster after that. I understand that recreating iconic courses like this is very expensive and time consuming, but it's a little disappointing nonetheless. This is one of the games I hope they release DLC for. I would gladly fork out some cash for some more content of this quality. tl;drOne of the best rally experiences ever created. Get it if you're a rally fan and are up for a challenge.

number of helpful: 7 of 7 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 13, 2016
Brief summaryOf all current rally games, DiRT Rally is one truly great game for those looking for an exhilerating, intense and fun experience; therefore, it really is one of my favourite on-the-edge-of-the-seat driving games. There are a lot of cars and various real-life stages with the challenging bumps and road width, and the co-driver is generally excellent in guiding through stages. Cars generally feel and sound fantastic on gravel and snow. The only downside for me is the unrealistic tyre model and  abrupt dynamic behaviour on asphalt. On the whole, I would wholeheartedly recommend DiRT Rally to anyone to enjoys the exciting world of motorsports. 8.5/10._________Cars and tracksThere are plenty of iconic rally cars from several classes, such as modern WRC machines, classic ‘70s, contemporary R4 cars to vehicles from the Group B era. In total, thirty-nine cars are available, and it is very noticeable that each have a specific handling. Thirty of these cars are available to drive in point-to-point rally stages. One particularly good aspect is that most of the cars sound very realistic in engine noise, and that they really seem to have a raw roar/irregularity to them as heard in their real-life counterparts. There is an upgrading system in the career mode; cars start out underpowered and overweight, and only after driving them several hundreds of kilometers, they will have the correct figures. Consequently, drivers that do not belong to the top 5% or so will have a hard time to win rally stages until they drive further.In terms of tracks, currently there are six countries: Greece, Monaco, Finland, Sweden, Wales and Germany. Each country features two unique long stages, which are around the 10 km mark, or between the high six and low eight minutes of driving time, depending on driving skill. Smaller stages are just segments from all the main stages. Furthermore, the stages are also offered to be driven in backward direction for more variation. The best thing, however, is that these tracks are modeled after parts of real rally stages. Stages can be very bumpy and upsetting cars, and at times are very treacherously narrow. When the co-driver calls a ‘caution’, it is imperative to drive slower and more accurately in order to avoid crashes. In my opinion, this aspect really makes the game fantastic to play. The only downside is that stages tend to be somewhat repetitive since one rally can consists of short stages which appear again as longer stages. Additionally, players who play this game many, many hours will find that at one point the stages have become familiar and that a co-driver is not necessary anymore, which personally takes a slight bit of fun out of the game. From that point of view, it can be argued that more track variety is needed, but I feel that the game offers plenty of tracks for at least several tens of hours of fun. Next to normal rallying, there are three rallycross circuits and a few special rallycross cars with up to 600 horsepower. Additionally, there is the Pikes Peak hillclimb, which is being offered in a fully-paved layout and a part gravel, part asphalt layout. Currently, there are a few historical hillclimb cars, such as the Audi Quattro S1 and the Peugeots 405 and 205 T16. Overall, content-wise there is much to offer, in my opinion. Game modesThere is a career mode, in which rally stages are offered sequentially per country. While changing between countries, it is possible to switch cars. Online multiplayer is offered only in rallycross mode, sadly. For point-to-point rally stages, the only multiplayer component is comparing stage times with friends or the rest of the world. Furthermore, it is possible to setup specific leagues with set rules and regulations, and there are periodic events organized by the developers that offer nice moneraty rewards. Co-driverOne of the best features in the game; the notes are clear and when set to ‘very early’, most of the time are very reliable in facilitating driving fast down a road that is not entirely familiar to the driver in advance. In high speed corners, the co-driver also talks faster and in a more severe tone, while he is calmer when driving slower. There are only a few slight mistakes in corner severity numbers being called, but overall the accuracy is very high. I find it a joy to drive without the HUD and being able to fully depend on the co-driver in this game. Driving dynamicsAnother important aspect that has made the game so much fun for me is the handling. In basic terms of dynamics, the cars feel realistic; modern WRC machines are very neutral, have very short braking distances and carry enormous amounts of speed through corners with high control, whilst older rear-wheel drive cars (especially from Group B) are very twitchy and unforgiving under power, depending on the exact car model. While playing, it is not uncommon to spin under power, and avoiding such a spin is hugely satisfactory. All other cars sit in between these two extremes; generally, the older the car, the lower the overall stability of the cars during acceleration, braking and coasting. What I also like, is that any driving over the limit will result in brushing the walls or trees, often resulting in car damage or at the very least a loss of time. It makes the game challenging, but also very rewarding at the same time. Personally, I find the handling of DiRT Rally on gravel (Wales, Greece, Finland) the most realistic: braking distances are longer now compared to the previous early-access handling and feel spot-on. Furthermore, cars do not loose too much momentum when sliding sideways through corners, but instead it is simulated that the wheels dig into the gravel surface and generate more lateral grip. The quantity of weight transfer (or actually wheel load transfer) on this surface feels the most accurate to me, because it is possible to make the car ‘dance’ between corners while being sideways. The same applies to pure snow and ice (Sweden and parts of Monaco); there is a fluidity in the cars handling that requires a certain precision in throttle, braking and steering inputs. However, the cars may be too forgiving when exaggerating inputs, which brings me to the remaining surface: asphalt (Germany and parts of Monaco). This is where the game is at its weakest; there seems to be no realistic relation whatsoever between grip and slip angle (the difference between the angle of the front wheels and the general direction the car is travelling in). The problem is that there is a lot of grip when expected, but that grip loss happens very abruptly and untrue to rubber tyres on asphalt.  At higher speeds above 100 km/h or so, it is not too bad, since cars do grip and generally understeer under power when going too fast through a corner. However, at these speeds there is too little sideways slip, so driving sideways and having to correct with the steering in third gear or higher like in onboards videos on Youtube is sadly not possible. The lower speeds is where the handling simulations lacks the most: this is where the cars do oversteer, but the rate of angular acceleration is far too great to be believable. Unfortunately, this phenomenon also means that the best stage times are achieved with a lower steering angle settings since slides can be corrected quicker and unfrotunately, without a loss of stability. In real life, the fastest way would be balancing between too much and too little steering input, and for that reason, I personally always set my steering wheel at 900° of steering and therefore always lose some speed, even though the recommended by Codemasters is 540°, and the fastest people even use 270° or less. Despite this crazy car behaviour and optional 'physics cheat', the driving is still sufficiently enjoyable on tarmac. Still not great compared to gravel handling, but acceptible.

number of helpful: 8 of 9 people (89%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2015
												This and Toybox Turbos are both examples of what Codemasters can do when they rein in the budgets and give their titles focus. Both titles benefit, and we finally get to see another fully realistic rally game as a result. The controls have no weird kinks, there's no overlong segues between menus, it's just pick how long you wanna race for, pick the car you wanna race in and a loading screen later you're on a track.You might be scared into thinking that a fully realistic rally game would demand a several-thousand-dollar Fanatec setup, but I've been playing this game on a cheap Ikea desk with a Logitech gamepad for half a year and I can get top-100 times using just that. It takes practise, sure, but no more than on that complex sim setup.This game is now out of Early Access, and there's two main gameplay modes: Time trials on special stages, as in classic rally tradition; and Rally Cross, that being a six-car race on a short track with a mix of on-road and off-road sections. There's no tutorial, this game relies entirely on its progression mechanics as a way to teach you. You get just enough money to buy a slow 1960s car and you get pitted against other equally slow 1960s cars. The game also makes it explicit that you have no chance to win your first few championships by having you earn upgrades every time you use your car, its way of saying that it's okay to take it slow and just learn how to handle the machine you're in. Those first stages become oddly relaxing, and an exercise in just learning the track and the car.There's other similarly relaxing mechanics in place. You start with a mechanics team who can't properly mend your car after a stage, and you won't be able to pay for one for some time. You're forced to make the decision between driving fast and suffering on a later stage, or driving slow and- oh hold on, I got a better time. That's the beauty of it, the game teaches you to drive slow without ♥♥♥♥ing up, and thereby saving you tens of seconds. Contrast this with Dirt 2 and Dirt 3. You'd start with cars that go too fast, handle terribly, your only clue for how to drive is a literal rainbow road and instead of a proper tutorial or forcing you to learn your car, those games just had a mulligan button. As soon as you learned how that first car drove, every car after would be a cakewalk. Dirt Rally shows that you can have proper teaching tools AND be fun AND be a completely realistic simulation at the same time, and it's very much to Codemasters' credit for achieving that.There's some excellent asymmetric multiplayer going on. The last few Codemasters games did have online leaderboards but this game takes that aspect and really runs with it. You can create your own league where your friends can join in and post times on specific events, any time of day they want. It's a great way to keep a group of friends competing with each other.I do have one complaint: Dirt Rally could do with some optimization. Some stages play at a stable 120+ FPS, others might dip below 30 on the exact same settings, including weather. Setting weather to High (not Low, which is slower) and trees to Very Low helps. It's odd.This game has some great voice acting. It's only one actor, he only plays one role, and he's your copilot. There's genuine nervousness in the way he reads his notes, at times he skips a beat and you just know going through all this he's pumped up on adrenaline. It's the perfect way to fill in the silence left by the menu music, and lends a lot to the game's serious racing atmosphere. Though the fact that he makes wrong calls is a bit unnerving. Not sure if that's a bug.I heartily recommend this game.

number of helpful: 8 of 9 people (89%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 1, 2016
												I have only just bought and played 2 stages, but already I am in love with it! I kind of loved Dirt 2, and parts of Dirt 3 were excellent, but the mandatory Gymkhana crap ruined the game...I really only enjoyed the straight rally races and trailblazer game modes, which were very enjoyable.Dirt 3 held your hand way too much as well with driving assists etc. overall it felt like a step backwards from Dirt 2. Dirt Rally feels more like Dirt 2, but more difficult and much less arcade like, which just makes it all the more rewarding.This game...This game is fairly unforgiving of your mistakes, but still manages to feel awesome! Love it so far. I found myself clenching my jaw (and my butt cheeks!) quite a bit. A good rush to be had. The sense of speed is impressive.Graphics are great and the sound design is also very satisfying. Performance never dropped below 60 on ultra with a GTX970 at 1440p.I have recently tried hacking together a VR headset with my phone, with some success, but the set up wasn't anywhere near perfect...This game might be just the motivation I need to tweak that set-up to perfection!*OCULUS THRIFT VR UPDATE* Ok, so using my phone, a BOBOVR Z4 headset, and some software trickery (to get the game into 3D and trick Nvidia into thinking my phone is a shield device), I was able to get low latency, decent framerate, wireless VR working with this game.The software is Trinus VR (which you install on the phone and the PC), Moonlight (which you install on the phone to make Nvidia think it is a shield) and Tridef 3D (which converts the game into 3D, but possibly isn't needed? I'm sure there are other ways to do it, I just haven't figured out how yet). The last piece of software is called OpenTrack, which you install on your phone and PC and it wirelessly transmits the head-tracking info from the phone to the PC.The resolution is only 1080p, but the frame-rate is generally pretty good (close to 60 with a few drops here and there). Motion tracking seems to work well, but to be honest, you rarely want to look anywhere but straight forwards unless you enjoy crashing a lot...Setting it up and getting everything running wasn't exactly a walk in the park (still a few disconnection issues to figure out), and even after getting things working, tweaking Trinus VR to get the image right for my headset took a decent amount of time too (a lot of pausing the game, disconnecting from the wireless streaming service, tweaking, reconnecting and repeat, until it was good enough.I haven't used an Oculus DK2 or Razer HDK1, but I imagine that the visual quality is about the same, for what amounts to a fraction of the cost. Worth checking out if you want to get a feel for VR without breaking the bank.If I have time, I might throw together a tutorial to show folks how I got it working. There are guides around for the smartphone VR setup, but none that solved everything for me. I had to use bits from several to find a working solution.

content:
Posted: August 3, 2015
Early Access Review
								DiRT Rally is one of those simulator games where players can gain an appreciation of how freaking difficult it is to be a rally driver. Seriously, it must take some massive genitalia to be able to drive this fast.Some notes for you all;-RWD cars slip and slide like it's constantly raining, and that's just on the gravel/asphalt tracks.-You MUST throw the car into corners to get it to turn, but too much and it launches into the wall.-After attempts at what must have been 100 hairpin turns, I finally managed to pull off a scandinavian flick and I was f***ing proud of myself.-Playing with a controller (xbox/ps4) helps immensly, and if you have a racing wheel, it makes driving so much easier.-DO NOT ATTEMPT TO DRIVE THE HILLCLIMB CARS AT ALL - I repeat, the hillclimb cars only start pulling at 5000-6000 RPM and scream up until their max RPM, where you are forced to change gears after only moving 10 metres. But hell they're fun.-Driving in Manual is way too much fun, don't even bother starting with automatic if you want a challenge.Hell, after writing all of this I want to go try a stage without crashing. Maybe.One heck of a game that will keep getting better as time goes on.

content:

Early Access Review
								I have always liked a casual dabble with an arcade racer, even a bit of Forza occasionally.  But, midway through a love affair with Driveclub I came across Dirt Rally.   That was a few weeks back and I haven't played anything since.  It's incredible and I didn't even realise that I liked sim rally racing.It's definitely difficult but somehow that makes it more accessible, which is weird.  It's like the Dark Souls of racing games.  And it's a beauty to look at and runs extremely well on a pretty modest PC (1st gen i5 and 2Gb 7870 here).I have hundreds of hours gameplay left with this game, and even after I've seen everything in the game, I can imagine playing this for a long time just because it's so exciting.Lastly, I did have fun with a pad, but pretty soon I realised I needed a wheel so bought a secondhand Logitech DFGT for peanuts, and it's so much more satisfying and fun to play.  So, I'd recommend getting at least a budget FFB wheel and if you are on a budget I don't think the DFGT can be beat.

content:
Posted: May 10, 2015
Early Access Review
								Best rally game in a long, long while. Unlike previous games in the DiRT series, DR leans more towards proper simulation. There are no flashbacks, you can't repeat races indefinitely, you can't turn off car damage and time penalties for car recovery are very harsh. You can also tune your ride to your own preference, gain upgrades, and hire a team of mechanics to keep your car in good shape.As the title implies, this game is all about rallying, so say goodbye to Gymkhana and "BRO SICK RACE BRO, YOU GOTTA POST THAT ON YOUTUBE" ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. The tracks are really good, they're well designed, the circuits are longer than before and the environments look impressive. Car physics are stellar, you can literally feel every bump on the road. And the audio is just superb, you can hear the gravel hitting your car, you can hear the brakes grinding when you push them too far etc. As far as i can tell, the game is also really well optimized. Quality work.DiRT Rally is in early access, but it's already rich in content, and it's going to grow at least twice in size before release. In my opinion, it already feels like the best rally game Codemasters ever made.

number of helpful: 7 of 8 people (88%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 31, 2015
												Short version. Dirt Rally is an immersive and challenging racing game, but with questionable driving physics. Meaning it was fun to learn, but it finally got tiresome.I have a lot of hours in this game and I did enjoy it, so it seems unfair to give it a negative review. But I stopped playing it for two months and when I recently came back, I couldn't finish a stage! I now realize that this is a difficult arcade game; the challenge is addictive and is complemented by pleasant visuals, great sound design and fine racing tracks. But the driving model is unintuitive, with arguably inaccurate physics.Tarmac handling is bad. The rear wheels are very light and drifty, and braking is vague; wheel lock occurs very late. It was so bad for the Hillclimb cars that they had to patch it. But it remains terrible for the RX supercars. Gravel has more balanced grip, but it is too high! You can annihilate Vatanen's time in Pike's Peak.Grip in Sweden seems to come and go haphazardly... you can't drive aggressively!Finland has absurd jumps and is too wide. Vehicles feel very stiff; they bounce too much from small bumps. Cars lack rotational momentum. Combined with the high gravel grip, using the handbrake is too easy, and Scandinavian flicks are ineffective for most cars. Without the handbrake, there is a lot of understeer! Except for the RWDs, which have incredible lift-off oversteer (R5 and Manta excluded).Car dynamics look unnatural in replays; cars seems to be rotating around a central axis.Career mode is quite repetitive, and you need to spend game credits to participate in events.Car repair is odd; you can repair parts 1% at a time.The automatic reset when hitting spectators or going off track is jarring.Again, the game is good if you are looking for a challenging rally experience. But given that is it described as the "most authentic rally game ever made" I can't recommend it.

content:
Posted: June 4, 2016
												This is the most passive-aggressive game ever created.For years now, us video game rally fans have been begging Codemasters to drop the insufferably bad Xtreme Sports hoo-hah that had plagued their once loved rally franchise. We wanted a return to serious rally racing sims without the brotard, Mountain Dew-fueled poop of the previous DiRT games. You just KNEW Colin McRae was rolling around in his grave. So, the Codies, likely sick of hearing the complaining released the single most soul crushing, nut grinding rally game ever in DiRT Rally. It's a rally sim. There's nary a car-fu (or whatever stupid name that stunt event had in previous entries) and this game will eat your soul. It's everything we wanted and I couldn't be happier with it!!!At this early stage of play, I suck really, really hard at it. I have all of the assists on and, counting penalties, I finish each race stage in just under six weeks. My 17-month-old daughter could do at least as well. But when you do something right, you know it happened because you got good at something and were not just lucky. It's rare with modern games that a video game rewards learned skill. When you start doing things right in DiRT Rally, it's completely rewarding.

content:
Posted: December 25, 2016
												An absolutely stunning experience with a racing wheel.This game leans more towards sim than it does arcade, the physics are far more realistic than previous DiRT games, although I can't say I'ev ever driven a real rally car. The point is it's harder, much harder, but this makes it so much more rewarding. Nailing slides and jumps really feels like an achievement. You will crash, a lot, and end up restarting stages time and time again, but in doing so you force yourself to improve.The graphics and sounds are great. My rig is an i7 4790k, 16 Gb RAM, GTX 970, and it runs on ultra with 80-120 frames. Graphics feel more realistic than most games due to the lack of saturation, and sounds really do add to the immersion.As for force feedback in the wheel, I'm having a great experience on my Thrustmaster T300RS. I do feel like a gearstick/handbrake would be ideal for this game however as pressing a button on the wheel is awkward.Online servers are currently down, but a quick trip to reddit tells me this is temporary and will most likely be fixed post-boxing day.Overall I'd say this is as, if not more enjoyable than F1 2016 (another excellent Codemasters title). It certainly beats any dirt game to date.8.5/10

content:
Posted: February 11
TL/DR REVIEW: Awesome!DIRT Rally very different from the previous installments of DIRT games. Instead of the usual arcade approach, this game gives players a believable, unforgiving rally simulation experience. This is a very welcome change of pace. With a wheel it's an absolute blast. My only two complaints/wishes are for there to be more stages and/or some kind of stage editor, and for the tarmac to be better simulated in the game. Dirt Rally has a lot of different environments, but unfortunately only a couple stages per location.Final noteThis is not an in depth or complete review of the game. It simply sums up my experience with the game in an effort to help you make a more informed purchasing decision.

content:
Posted: December 8, 2015
												TL;DR: BESTRACINGGAMEEVER+It's challenging. This game isn't going to hold your hand and may make small children cry. +80-90% realistic handling / 10% "arcadey" of all vehicles +it's almost exclusively rally and hillclimb;  baby circuit racing "rallycross" is tacked on for multiplayer but you don't even have to touch it when playing through the career +realistic pacenotes spoken by your co-driver+TUNING, REPAIRS, UPGRADES, LIVERIES - e.g., you get a flat during a run - fix it instantly for a massive time penalty+Liveries don't appeal to the dudebro demographic - no Subarus covered in obnoxiously large Monster™ logos+ALL of the WIDE VARIETY of classic rally cars are cars that you would actually WANT to drive. You won't find 80 variations of a Nissan Skyline here *cough*GranTurismo5*cough*+According to the store description there are 70 rallies for you to enjoy racing the clock on - yes, a good chunk of them are reversed versions of the same stage, but the stages are so varied in what turns and jumps you have to tackle it doesn't even matter to the point where it would be annoying to NOT get reversed stages+Asode from all the fantastic gameplay features. the scenery you will encounter while rushing past trees at 130 kph is absolutely breathtaking.+The game runs at a solid, stable 60 fps without a hitch and zero issuesI may add more to this review as I unfold and explore this masterpiece of visual pleasurement.

content:
Posted: May 5, 2015
Early Access Review
								In my early access review I said that this game wasn't better than RBR. Now that this game has got brand new handling system and steering wheel support, I can happily say that Richard Burns Rally (published in 2004) has finally got another game to it's side in the legendary group of rally racing games. The handling is perfect for a steering wheel (I've got CSR Forza wheel), and the graphics and physics are awesome. This game is totally a simulation, not a crappy arcade game with cars going on rails like the older Dirt games. Although if you don't have a controller or a steering wheel, this game might be too hard for you. Just saying, the carreer mode is really hard.Another point I'd like to say, is that this game has free (YES, LITERALLY FREE) updates every month. I just hope they keep updating the game. If done so, this game will have a long lifespan.TL;DR: Awesome game, everything's good.Thank you codemasters for making this game.

number of helpful: 8 of 10 people (80%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 28, 2015
												For now this is the best rally game since Richard Burns Rally. If everything goes well, it could be the best rally sim since RBR.A pure rally sim is what we need after so many years.//////////Edit 2015/5/27:For now, I have to change some of my previous thoughts about this game.I've played almost all CodeMaster racing games except some F1 series, they all feel the same. CodeMaster made all their racing games feel like you are driving on ice. I feel better the days before Dirt, the whole EGO engine times. Dirt, dirt2, dirt 3, dirt count down, grid, grid 2, grid autosport, fuel, F1 2011, F1 2012, F1 2014, every EGO titles I can remember, they all feel the same---driving like on ice.I think CodeMaster never hired some real driver to qualify the car physics, and almost every racing titles CM made are better controlled on joysticks/gamepads rather than on racing wheels. We invited many people who has deep real world driving experiences including some real racer to try out many CodeMaster racing titles both on gamepad and racing wheels. All of them can drive pretty good on racing wheels with racing sims like rFactor, iRacing, NFS13, Simbin titles, the new AC. But few of them feel good on any CodeMaster racing titles when driving with racing wheels. It just feels too fake on the car physics. CodeMaster racing games only perform good with controllers like gamepads.Till now, after many hours of test drive in Dirt Rally, I admit everything goes better except car physics.Is this one a Richard Burns Rally successor? Definitely not. Maybe some arcade racing fans would like this. But for a sim racer? Let's go back and play RBR.I may change the advisory after its official release to "Not Recommended". Just be prepared.Edit Sep 18th, 2016:I bought this game very early right after its early access release, you may not be able to see my review since the new Steam review system change. And now I have over hundreds of hours of playing time on it.I still recommend it to any race fans, rally fans, car fans. It's definitely one of the best rally games since Richard Burns Rally. It's a rally race game you can enjoy hours after hours with racing wheels or just a good mechanical keyboard.I think every little bit of things are good or even exellent in DiRT Rally. Despite some kids may not get fully understoodment of what a "Race Sim" should be, they may feel it being too hard to drive. But one knows he should follow traffic rules in real life driving, how could he not follow the same rules driving in a race sim? Or a semi-sim. Everything feels right of this title for now. EXCEPT ONE: the physics.I don't have much real world driving experience, I have some in Richard Burns Rally, which I played since my 9 grade class and played it almost 10 years. DiRT Rally lacks a proper physics as being a modern race sim comparing to the 14-year-old Richard Burns Rally. The later one does it better here. But this may not be a problem for a casual gamer who just want to kick the throttle and accelerate to hundreds of kilometers per hour speed and drift like there is no Newton Law at all. The most obvious feel is that the car is too light and whenever it hit something it just bump up into the air. You will feel that as long as you play.I think Codemasters is trying to find a balanced point where they can satisfy casual race gamers and semi-sim race gamers. If so, DiRT Rally has done a great job.

number of helpful: 8 of 10 people (80%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 1, 2016
												This game is a masterpiece, simply said. All simulators should look up to this. Over a year has passed since Early Access, and we all saw this game evolve. There were monthly updates and constant patches that brought this game to it's full glory. Constantly adding new cars and tracks, tweaks and new game modes. This game has really realistic engine, cars are badass, from early '60s to Modern Beasts, it has it all. It has rally on every type of surface (Dirt,Gravel,Snow,Tarmac,Ice..) , to every weather condition possible (Sunny,Rain,Snowy,Fog..). Career mode is well designed and really entertaining, making you start rally with '60 vehicles, and then you slowly progress trough generations of cars. There is hillclimb, featuring Pikes Peak, 20km huge hillclimb. In hillclimb there is 2 car classes and 3 types of surfaces. Also there is WorldRX also known as RallyCross, where you have 3 classes (Since  of Console Release) and RallyCross also has Multiplayer feature. This game currently has 6 Rallys and 9 car classes ('60s, '70s, '80s, Group B [AWD], Group B [RWD], Group A, F2 Kit Car, R4, 2000s, 2010s). So yeah this game has everything for everyones taste. Game is really difficult, winning a stage on this game, not rally, a stage makes you fell like you are on top of the world. Game is really unforgiving and requires huge skill and lots and lots of practise! If you are a car lover, this is a must have!Verdict: Amazing+ Lots of Content for Everyones Taste+ Challenging Experience+ Simulation+ Visuals, Sound and Gameplay are Amazing+ Brilliant Handling

												If you're a finisher and coming first is a given, do not buy this game. If you don't think you need to learn how to drive properly, do not buy this game. If you want to receive podium accolades for "great" driving, do not buy this game. If you're playing with a keyboard, do not buy this game. If you think sideways is the fastest way to exit a corner, do not buy this game. If you don't like to sweat profusely, after a 9 minute hill climb,  do not buy this game. If stopping to mend a flat tyre is too much trouble, do not buy this game. If learning why dampers are called dampers is too much trouble, do not buy this game. If 2/10ths is too small to bother with, do not buy this game. If a Skandanavian Flick means a cute Nordic blonde told you to go away, do not buy this game. If you want to drive rally, do. In a word. Pure.9.99/10Play it like a casual rally....

												So far I'm having fun time with the game. It drives really well and looks good; some people have said that it might not be a true sim experience, but it's definitely a hardcore game that requires you to really get into the mechanics if you want to get good results. Never driven a rally car, but those real life car handling techniques I'm familiar with work wonderfully here. The career system is actually very sim-like, you literally start at the bottom leagues with ancient cars and progress buying better ones, advancing forward after successful tournaments and events. It just feels so very slow if you were already used to modern cars in early access.And extra point for having very clear and simplistic menus, without throwing DLC constantly on your face (looking at you Dirt 3).

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 12, 2016
												DiRT Rally takes sport seriously, but it has some problems too.Pros:*Great driving - fun, responsive, each car feels different.*The tracks are dangerous and punishing*Driving with a steering wheel, with no HUD and assists (just the co-pilot) is a BLAST!*Graphics are nice*Online events create an amazing competitive feel and variety.Cons:*This game suffers from the syndrome where you fall out of the track and your car gets instantly put back, BUT sometimes it actually DNFs you and shows your car as unrecoverable. This makes no sense, since at times I can fall out quite far and be put back and at other times I get a DNF with sliding out just slightly and if you proceed, then you are DNF'd from the WHOLE EVENT - this makes ZERO sense. Sometimes you slide out quite slightly (experienced it mostly in winter stages), you get an ''unrecoverable car" and you can't even progress to the next stage) - and at other times I can hit a wall at 150 KM/h and keep racing. There is NO balance here...*The crashing visualisation is very weak compared to other Codemasters games - I was actually expecting, that I crash and destroy my car and it would make sense that I can't continue, but that doesn't happen. Sometimes it is too easy to blow my tire (after a minor crash) and at others I can't get any response from a crash. Read the previous point - it works together with graphics, where it almost always seems illogical, how you can/can't continue a race. The biggest issue for me is those annoying fade out->fade in(put back on track) sh*ts - it's stupid! Let me crash properly and make a proper response in visual and actual damage! (There is always a restart option.... except where there isn't)This game has a LOT of things I have always wanted in a real rally game, but others pull it back at being the same old same old. Generally, if you make to the end of the race and don't crash - it feels like the best thing EVER, until you crash....7,5/10 (it is a good score, btw - still recommended)

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 18, 2015
Early Access Review
								One of the best games I've been playing for a long time.I'm into racing simulations since I can think, but with the most game you either have a good racing sim, OR a nice career mode. Until Dirt Rally came up that technically combines a realistic feel with nice graphics and a career mode and multiplayer leagues that is fun to play.First of all, the support by the developers is OUTSTANDING. This is the first early access game that is fun to watch as it's doing a BIG progress with continuous updates and new non-DLC content. Frequently new stages, cars and even game modes have been released, handling is tweaked, bugs are fixed, performance improved - that's amazing. The developers really read the ideas and suggestions on the DIRT forums and implement respective functionality into the game. This is the first Early Access game where I can clearly feel the developers absolutely developing a game according to the player's feedback. So the many, many positive reviews here on Steam are very well deserved. The handling:I've been used to older Dirt games, but also played Richard Burns Rally a lot. RBR was supposed to be the most authentic rally sim and drifting in RBR was actually really easy. Somehow I believed that RBR is top of the notch and after playing Dirt Rally in a very early stage, I thought that Dirt Rally is far away from being realistic, because cars won't drift the way I want, engaging drifts and doing hairpins wasn't that easy as in other Rally Sims. However, the more I played, the more I noticed that the "unrealistic" handling is actually only a result of my bad driving skills, because in Dirt Rally you actually have to know what you do with your car and how to set up your car to make it drift the way you want. The more you learn about car physics and rally driving techniques, the more you'll notice that Dirt Really is very accurate in simulating the car handling under specific conditions. You can really feel a big difference in the setup and the different car types such as AWD, RWD and FWD. You can use all sorts of real world driving techniques to get these different cars to slide the way you want and it works pretty accurate. Whenever you do a crash thanks to oversteering or understeering, there always is a logic explanation of what caused the car to behave that way. Thus said, after 25 hours of drifting and sliding through the game, I honestly consider this to be the most authentic handling when it comes to rally games.The career mode:The career mode is actually a really nice one, at the moment divided into Classic Rally (With co-driver), Hill Climb (Without co-driver) and Rally Cross (The non-Dirt3-like realistic version). You're not going to participate in single events, but always in whole championships that are divided into different countries which again are divided into different rally stages. Once you're through all events and land on the podium on the end of the championship, you're allowed to participate in a more advanced championship with of course more advanced AI opponents. Thus said, the more you advance, the more difficult it gets. So as a beginner, you'll most likely have problems winning the first championship on the first try, but on the second try you most likely will. The championship system always ensures you got a proper competition, so the game is never too easy or too hard. It will keep you challenged, but it's not too frustrating. Indeed it is very motivating because you can clearly see how you improve your times and driving skills during time until you reach the next championship level. Also you got the ability to repair your car each and every two stages you drove. Your mechanics got half an hour to repair a wide selection of different car parts, all having an impact on the driving. If you drive stages at night, you better repair the head lights of your car before you tweak the suspension. So you always have to make wise decisions on what you actually are going to repair during that half hour. However, you can also entirely destroy your car so it's not repairable. If this happens, the championship is over and you'll loose everything.Team management:There is also the ability to manage your team. You can hire crew members, and the more skilled these people are, the more they cost, but therefor they need less time to repair specific car parts throughout the championship. You can check how long their contracts will run and you will have to make sure that none of the contracts is expiring during your championships. You can fire people, replace them, and your team will even level up the more you drive in events. Good stuff: It's not important to win to level up your team and car, but it's only important that you actually drive. The more KM you drove with team members hired, the more they will progress and level up. So even if you got stuck on a specific difficulty, driving and playing the games still provides a progress. If a specific member reached a level up, you have access to perks which you can buy to even improve the power of your team.Car upgrades:Another nice aspect is that when you play the championship events, not just your team levels up, but also your car. The more KM you've driven with the car with a specific team, the more your team is going to know your car. So after some kilometers/time, your team starts to install weight reductions/engine and turbo upgrades to your car. Means the more you drive an actual car in your garage, the faster and more powerful it gets since your team keeps improving it. So even without winning championships, you're still earning money for new cars and upgrades for existing cars that make your favorite cars even faster.Multiplayer leagues:You can register and create an account on the RaceNet website, allowing you to keep track of your progress and driving statistics, comparing yourself to other real drivers and participate in online multiplayer events. Also you can race Rally Cross events together with other people on the same track, so you can actually crash and bump into them. This is nice to see your skills and times compared to other real world players.Graphics:Nothing much to say - the graphics are outstanding for a simulation game and look really good. On ultra settings on my machine it sometimes doesn't look exactly as nice as the preview images in Steam, but generally the graphics are nothing someone can moan about. That's all I had to say - this game is technically outstanding and unique in many, many ways. Plus in some months there will even more features by the developers that have not been taken into account on this review. I can just recommend this game to ANYONE who is either a rally fan, likes racing games in general or pure simulations. Everyone is going to have fun with this kind of game, no matter if you like the simulation or if you want to play it with a game pad in an arcade style. Definitely a big recommendation from my side.
