Posted: December 18, 2015
												Best rally sim since RBR handsdown.+Graphics 9/10Good. Doesnt leave anything to be desired.+Sound 8/10I really love the sound of gravel spraying to the cars body and the engine sounds are beautiful. Some points are taken by little bit unclear co-driver notes. You can crank the volume way up and hear the notes better but i think they shoud have gone for more "dry" eq sound to distinguish the notes from the background noise.+Handling 9/10Feel for the road is really good. Force feedback works well and is tunable to  a good extent.+Cars 9/10Different cars have different characteristics and feels. Tuning your cars setup really makes a big difference. Group B cars <3.-1 point for not having custom liverys. +Tracks 10/10There is a good variety of rally stages and conditions. The stages are really detailed and challenging. Flying Finland is one of my favorite locations. You spend half the time soaring thru the air at those stages, its just crasy.-Damage modelling +6/10There are different types of damage to the car like punctured tyres etc. but i would like to see better body damage modelling because at this point it doesnt really seem to affect the driving too much when you collide with a rock or a tree at high speed.For the overall score i would give 9/10This game is what i have been waiting for since rbr started to get out dated.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 11, 2015
Early Access Review
								DiRT Rally is an amazing game plagued by one potentially experience-ruining issue.Visually, the game is superb. The game performs well on a variety of hardware (having personally tested it both with an older HD 6870 1 Gb and a brand new R9 380 4 Gb) and has excellent lighting and texture/detail features. There is some rather annoying dithering to plant life, but that's forgivable, and usually does little or nothing to hurt the experience. Menus are well-designed and simple, too, making navigation through the game's options easy for beginners but powerful for advanced users.Likewise, both sound and physics are absolutely wonderful as well. Cars control like cars, with all the quirks and difficulties thereof, though the game already offers a number of difficulty tuning options to make handling easier or more realistic depending on your preferences. Music is minimal, but appropriate when it is present, and all the vehicles sound unique, with a well-voiced navigator at your side whose vital help never grows annoying.If so much is right, then what is the problem?The save system.Simply put, disable Steam cloud saves first thing, and hope to your chosen deity that that fixes the issue, though in some (or even many) cases it won't. The game has a bad tendency to lose save data, costing players hours of progress, often in an unpredictable pattern, with the data safe one session and gone the next.The game is still Early Access, and for an early access title the feature suite and performance are superb. However, if the save feature is not fixed by launch, then that alone will make or break this game's value to many players, since progress is neither arbitrary nor fast. However, if the risk of losing save data doesn't scare you, then this is most definitely the racing game you've been waiting for.

content:
Posted: January 6, 2016
												If you want a rally game look no further!I absolutely love this game. It's so refreshing to play a game that just simply works. Like back in the day when you had a ps2 and just put the game in and never worried about bugs or glitches or crashes. This game is so well optimized that I tried downsampling from 4k (I only have a 1080p monitor) on my gtx 970 and with the high graphics preset I had a solid 60 fps. I'm amazed I can run this game at 4k with high settings on a single 970 at 60 fps. This game runs beautifully and it just looks amazing. Now onto the game itself I also love what is has to offer. I'm not a hardcore racing sim fan so I can't give too much input on the realism but to me it's perfect. It could probably be a little more realistic with the brake control but other than that the cars feel responsive and the amount of traction feels right for whatever terrain you're on. It has the perfect amount of challenge and learning curve in my opinion. The co-driver call outs are great and you absolutely must pay attention and listen to them or you'll end up flying off the track. I feel there could be a bit more tracks though as I was a little surprised when it came out of Early Access but there's a fair amount. I wouldn't say the game is lacking in content but I can't say there's a ton either. There's I think 6 different main rally courses in seperate countries and within each of those 6 there are 12 or so different sections to play. That may sound like a ton but tose 12 include backwards versions of the same tracks and larger sections that just connects 2 smaller tracks. All of the courses look really good though and they all feel different and like a real course.But as for cars there are plenty to choose from. I'm no rally expert but to me most any kind of popular rally car out there is in the game. And the sound of the cars is incredible. I can't get over the sound of the cars. Everything just sounds so right, the engines bounce off the limiter and they pop on decel and it just sounds amazing. I love the sounds. Can't really describe them so you'll just have to get the game and find out!Also a side note I love the crowds in this game. Usually in racing games they'll just copy and paste 2d or really horrible 3d people around the track that look OK if you fly by them but look god awful up close. In Dirt Rally though the crowd is actually made up of greatly modeled 3d characters that are actually highly varied in appearance and they all aren't doing the same 3 stupid annimations. Just a small side note but that's always a pet peeve of mine is when they skimp on crowds but here they look great, even up close!All in all this game is a must if you like rally or any kind of off road racing!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 9, 2015
Early Access Review
								Very impressed. I didn't believe codemasters when they said their next title would actually be focused on true rally. Turns out I was wrong.Currently, I would like to see a few fairly minor tweaks to a few aspects of the physics model, a little more aggressive damage and some FFB tweaks (manually editing the config file really improved things to the point that I'm happy with the current state). Codemasters has been very receptive to customer feedback and appear to be working on all these points.As it stands, I would not be disappointed with exactly what I have received, even if we weren't going to get any futher updates. I think there's strong potential for an RBR replacement here.Graphics, performance, stability... All very acceptable at 2160p native. Good work, codemasters. You've disappointed me for years after dropping the Colin Mcrea titles and moving to 'dirt'. This title is a true 180 that I fully support.I plan on updating this review as development progresses.

content:

Early Access Review
								This game is mega super fun. No matter what car or track you choose it's a challenge just to get through the race without crashing. I don't know whether it's realistic as a simulator or not but it seems like it could be for the most part. I've only played with an xbox controller so far and it feels great. I recommend driving manual and utilizing the handbreak turning as it adds a lot to the experience. Once you start getting good enough to actually finish a race it becomes a real rush trying to improve your times because of the thin and bumpy tracks. If you lose focus for half a second you'll soon find yourself upside down in a ditch with a missing tire and a cracked windshield.+ Immersion (incredibly good sound, nice graphics, physics seems reasonably real).+ Challenge (You need to be awake while hurtling a 2000 pound machine down a bumpy forrest trail at 80 MPH).  + Early acces (The game will improve over time).- fov settings limited, had to edit the config file to get it right with triple monitor setup.- Although I've not experienced this my self as I have no wheel, some people have reported poor ffb with theirs. But I believe they will address this issue.Strongly recommed.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 29, 2015
Early Access Review
								It's still early access but this game is shaping up to be awesome. I've played pretty much every rally game that's come out for the PC since the late 90's, Mobil 1 Rally Championship, Colin McRae, Dirt, Richard Burns Rally, you name it I've played them and this is up there with RBR and M1RC as one of the greats.Handling feels pretty realistic in that cars aren't on rails, you can't let off the gas to make every turn at near full speed, damage is pretty realistic in that a slight off can puncture a tire and do some bad damage. The stages are longer than in DIRT but not nearly as long as M1RC or even some RBR stages, but they're decently long at about 6-8 minutes for the majority.There are a lot of different types of cars and they do feel realistic for their age, ie: modern WRC cars are insanely fast and handle a lot better than some of the early FWD rally cars (Mini). If you want a really good rally game that looks pretty pick this up as soon as you can, I don't think you'll regret it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 29, 2016
												So is Dirt Rally any good?  Well one thing i can say is thank god Codemasters have finally done away with all this fist bumping Gymkana nonsence and taken the series back to its rallying roots. After purchasing your 1st car... (I chose the 1960's mini.) you can take up a career ralling your way to victory...(or not), and become a legend in the Rally scene. Let me point out that Dirt rally is bloody hard. There are no rewinds in Dirt Rally so one mistake can lose you valuble seconds. As i'm sure most of you know its best to hit this game with a control pad or steering wheel setup. im currently using the Xbox one control pad. Dirt Rally is very good but it still has issues that need patching. Im using a AMD 3.5 GHZ cpu with 16 gig of ram and a GTX 960 GPU. I can run the game with everything on High and it runs very smooth. Between 60 to 120 FPS however after using the game for about 20 mins i encounter micro stutter for about 10 to 15 seconds that will put the best of us off our game. Considering you need alot of conentration during the stages to stand a chance of finishing 1st, its not good to have a major drop in FPS. Having said that, even when i have the steam FPS counter in the corner, its still registering 60 + FPS during the stutter so i'm thinking maybe a memory leak. Other than that Dirt Rally is a joy to play and if you enjoyed any of the original Rally games of times past then i highly recommend it to any rally or racing fan.

								Developing and releasing a rally game nowadays must be a hard sell for a publisher. "Not popular enough, not enough sales" they might say. content:
Posted: May 7, 2015
Early Access Review
								Well, first off I must say that this game was wayyyy different than I thought it would be. The reason why I say this is because the other Code Master games I have played, such as the DiRT games have been far far easier than this game. This game is an actual simulation, not a racing game that is going to walk you through every aspect of its mechanics. Instead it dumps you on your face where you will fail time and time again until you start to understand the mechanics, or are used to rally car physic type stuff (or you destroy your keyboard/controller because you can't stay on the ♥♥♥♥ing track). In my opinion Code Masters took a very good turn as far as game types, and I think they should continue down this path. I definately reccomend this game if you are ready for a challenge, but overall this is a very, very rewarding game when you nail the physics of it and get that satisfying pay off.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 8, 2015
Early Access Review
								Firstly do not expect to pick up this game and win right away...it's very unlikely! The game feels unforgiving at first but patience and practice begin to pay off after just a couple of hours. The game is a superb blitz through Wales/Greece/Monte Carlo (at the moment) with Rally car through the ages. It's early access and more stages and hillclimbs are to come but there different styles and eras of cars keep you on your toes.One thing to do for sure is to make use of the shakedowns where possible to fine tune the set up of your car and understand the feel of the surface.I have been using Xbox controller for windows and have found this to be pretty decent although I imagine a wheel and pedal set up would give such a better feel.Although early access this is already shaping up to be a classic and one of the best Rally games ever. Daily, weekly and monthly online challenges enable you to challenge yourself against the world which keeps things fresh and adds some further excitment.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 9, 2015
Early Access Review
								This is such an amazing game, I haven't had this much fun in a rally game for a long time. Has a great car lineup (with more to come), and all of them true classic rally vehicles. There are 36 stages so far with plenty of stages clocking in at 5+ minutes across Greece, UK/Wales and Monte Carlo. I'll be honest that I've spent most of my time playing the British rally, it's just such a nostaglia rush to have a Ford Escort RS Coswoth or Subaru Impreza blasting along the Sweetlamb stage. I started playing rally videogames with the DOS-based Network Q RAC Rallly Championship game from 1996, and getting to race these 90's Group A cars across Wales is a blast from the past!Anyway, if you're a rally fan (particularly of the UK rally) then I would definitely give this game a look in. It's a difficult yet exciting take on the sport and a return to a more traditional rally game for the Dirt series which is very postivte I think. So get your wheel and pedals sets out and put your foot to the floor!  :D

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 4, 2015
Early Access Review
								Amazing. I don't write reviews for games, because . . .  i just don't. I read other reviews and I don't bother to add my voice to the chorus. But I feel inspired with DIRT RALLY because it is just . . . great. It's the rally game I always wanted. It's tough, but you feel progress as you become a better driver. It's freakin' gorgeous - just try and make your way across the hills of Wales on a wet, rainy afternoon and not look at the cliffs and trees off in the distance. It doesn't replace DIRT 3, which is a great arcade driver, but sits along side it in my collection as two of my most played games.  I can't believe this is "early access." If you like driving games, and you must if you are reading this and considering purchasing DIRT RALLY, do it. You won't be disappointed (just remember the value of practice).

												Dirt Rally, man... What a great game. It sure has it's own ups amd downs during the time of it's Early Access, such as bugs where the map doesn't load during the middle of the race and you be driving on nothing or fps problems with some update for myself but regardless of those few tiny problems that have came with the fact it is Early Access, this game is simple one of the best Dirt, CodeMaster and Rally games out there.Forcefeed back on a wheel is just outstanding, maps are outstanding with every little detail matter to the driver and the Rally Call out guys details are close to prefect I can play without any osd (On Screen Display) and on a nre mape and still know where I am going. The detail of inside every car is a new feeling in cockpit view and third person you can really get to see the pretty liverys this game has, must be over 50 different ones for all the vicheals easy!Pros :Update a lotIt is just rally at its best, its scary and it is so fun.Only game i've seen with a Hill ClimbA lot of choice to drive in and even maps with many more updates containing new mapsFeedback on wheel is amazingWill have PVPAnticheat for leaderboards (Also a con kinda since it not prefect yet but they will get it.)They are trying for mod support which regardless if it happens or doesn't I think it matter they are trying.Cons :It sometime has fps problems with updateJust normal bugs that come with Early Access (They get fixed super fast though!)For 40$ I think this game is well beon the money it cost, I feel like this game should cost like 60$ or more but its not, they only ask 40$ on your money and it is well worth it and if not! look steam gots refunds but I don't think you'll need them for this baby. Keep on rallying :) Hairpin turn coming up on left <3

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 22, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game is such a game changer for rally games I don't even know where to start.Graphics; If you have played DiRT 3, you will notice a distinct difference to begin with, but I found that actually it makes DiRT 3 look less realistic than I thought it was, this game looks real - if you have enough time to look at the scenery that is.Gameplay; This game is not for the arcade racer. There are plenty of assists, but I always pride myself on turning them all off. I did so for DiRT 3 and was still finding it quite easy. In this game the cars have real traction issues, grip is not consistent on surfaces and cars twitch at speed, much like real life. On gravel and snow with 0 ABS you have to use engine braking to burn speed coupled with braking otherwise you lock up and goodbye to your stage time. The tracks are long and different, even at alpha stage. It takes some time to get used to, but it is the first time I have geniunely smiled from ear to ear after coming second in a stage even though I was 10 seconds off the top spot.AI; The AI aren't super difficult, and they have bad runs sometimes, which keeps it interesting. The co driver is excellent and you have to really concentrate, but it pays off and is much more specific than DiRT 3.Audio; The cars sound raw, the sounds of the track help you decide how to tackle corners with changes in gravel density and ice patches. The co driver sounds shaky, as if he were in a rally car and gets nervous in places as his pace notes speed up.There aren't millions of cars, or hundreds of tracks but it doesn't matter. I use an Xbox 360 controller and I would say you should at least have one or a wheel for this but it is so worth it. I used to play Colin McRae Rally on PC and PS1 so much and DiRT 3 didn't feel like those games. This game goes back to what it is all aboutl; Serious Rallying. God I love this game and Codemasters. <3

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 8, 2015
Early Access Review
								For any fans of DiRT 3 that just felt something missing, this is your game. No Gymkhana BS, just pure rally goodness. Playing this game with a game controller works just fine, but to get the full DiRT Rally experience I highly recommend invensting in a FFB racing wheel if you do not own one already. There are many different car classes to choose from, including 1960's FWD clunkers, all the way up to modern day rally beasts. Beware, this game is as close to a rally simulation as one will find right now and therefor has a learning curve. This is a must have game for racing sim fans and especially rally racing fans.Pros:-Detailed car setup customization-Plents of real life tracks with innumerable stages in each-Realistic(ish) game physics (more in cons)-Team management-Challenging career championship system-Lots and lots of rally cars with all drive types (FWD, RWD, 4WD)Cons:-The edges of tracks do not seem to act very realistic (i.e. clip a bank on the outside of the track and send your car into a deadly barrel roll)-With my FFB racing wheel (Logitech Driving Force GT) I had to spend a few days tweaking the Logitech control panel as well as in-game settings to get the in-game FFB to feel rightOverall I would definitely give this game a 9/10 right now. Keep in mind that this game is an EARLY ACCESS title and Codemasters is working on fixing any issues and adding more content to the game to keep the player base enthralled in the gameplay. Since picking this game up a week ago, I have played for several hours every day. There is just something so satisfying about setting a great stage time and placing first in a championship.

content:
Posted: March 15, 2016
												I bought this game during early access, the moment it became available, played for a while, and recently got back to continue playing...I'll give it 8.5/10 !!This is my chill & just drive go to game, where I enjoy the driving process, handling is amazing, tracks are as well, and whenever I reach the end of a stage I just rewatch the replay, because it is A.MAZING !There are several categories to race in, hillclimbs, and small compact races.On race net there are new challanges every day, every week, and every month. Just playing those alone worths it.I played rally games looong time ago, played dirt 3, and a lot of other racing sims (AC, PCARS, GRiD Autosport), but out of EVERY car driving game I played ever since I've got my wheel, this is the most enjoyable, most competitive, and less frustrating !

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 13, 2016
												Wales! Wales is all about the mud. For fans of snow there is Sweden, Gravel fans can head to Finland or Greece and if you like a more standard road surface Germany has you covered. Finally, for those of you that like driving on sheets of ice with patches of tarmac, you can head to Monte Carlo.You will drive into trees in Wales and Finland, snowdrifts in Sweden, Drachenzähne and Hay bales in Germany, into walls in Monte Carlo and straight over a cliff in Greece. When you realise that haste is not the same as speed you will stop doing this and start having fun. Some may find the game frustrating, it is definitely not as forgiving as most titles (considerably more so than real life though) but if you put in some time you will find it rewarding, at least until you are promoted, buy a faster car and start driving into trees all over again...9/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 4, 2015
Early Access Review
Introduction:Overall/So far (8/4/15) this is a very solid game for PC racing fans. Keep in mind that this is a racing sim not just some fun casual racing game. If you're expecting an expansion of the DiRT series like 2 & 3 it's a very different game. Pros:Amazing graphicsRealistic PhysicsGreat Car soundsVery few bugs for Early AccessGood selection of carsGreat tracksOptimized quite wellAbility for masteryCons:Some times it's too realistic which is difficultWhen playing you can't chill and race, too realistic and AI is too good for that Very little car options (maybe because of early access..?)Restarting/Recovering is quite depriving and criplingRecording your gameplay is quite bad for performance (maybe just me)Conclusion:I would definatly recommend this since it isn't expensive and they are always adding free content throughout development. If you enjoy sim racing and rally/offroad racing this game will entertain you.For more reviews check out  Original Curators Group

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 3, 2015
Early Access Review
								Developing and releasing a rally game nowadays must be a hard sell for a publisher. "Not popular enough, not enough sales" they might say. "We will never recoup our costs" they might say.Releasing as early access they solved this politic issue and prolly got money when they needed it the most - for bug cleaning and tweaking.Loving it so far. Handling is superb imho. Lots of adjustments can be made but you can also turn on some assists if you need that as well. Nice balance there. The graphics are beautiful on Ultra; wish I had 3 monitors and a wheel.So happy the DIRT series didnt die and they went this route for the niche hardcores!If you love rally support the developers and buy this game you won't be disappointed.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 7, 2015
Early Access Review
								Well, first off I must say that this game was wayyyy different than I thought it would be. The reason why I say this is because the other Code Master games I have played, such as the DiRT games have been far far easier than this game. This game is an actual simulation, not a racing game that is going to walk you through every aspect of its mechanics. Instead it dumps you on your face where you will fail time and time again until you start to understand the mechanics, or are used to rally car physic type stuff (or you destroy your keyboard/controller because you can't stay on the ♥♥♥♥ing track). In my opinion Code Masters took a very good turn as far as game types, and I think they should continue down this path. I definately reccomend this game if you are ready for a challenge, but overall this is a very, very rewarding game when you nail the physics of it and get that satisfying pay off.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 2, 2015
Early Access Review
								My take on Dirt Rally (pre order release): Two words or less: Merciless Fun.The good, the bad, the ugly and the indifferent:Can't speak to controller land, I don't equate controller and SIM at all; it's like an oxymoron. That said, it's not really a SIM, it's a very serious game with some decent underpinnings and good enough visuals to get the job done. Be prepared to play with the FFB settings to get rid of the muddled center and spring action and tweak the rest of it to get what you want. Well at least get it close enough... Once tweaked the FFB is as passable as AC or Race Room; canned as the day is long but giving the appropriate info. This is with  the base Fanatec "4za" wheel with an Elite pedal set, other wheels will vary.One thing I lament right off the rip is the fact the wheel button/pedal schemes are cast in cement. It's 2015 not 1995... They say they're going to address this for different wheels which is great news, however I have to wonder if that will include telling the game I want to use a particular pedal or button for something regardless of input device. I am really hoping they get beyond the control schema looking at me stupid with a face full of "you want teh clutch pedal to do what..?" (...a clutch pedal that isn't usable in my pedal set ATM to boot, again something they purpose to fix...) The flexibility to add stand alone shifters and e-brakes for custom cockpits will go a long way towards immersion and aren't something I'd consider optional in this day and age, it would be a detriment to the title to leave this kind of thing out again.While we're weeping and wailing and gnashing teeth, the menu still being straight out of console land for a PC title is a bit bonehead classification worthy. You'll need to drag out your wheel manual and note what buttons are what numbers. Once I figured out where the buttons were it was navigable, I could even change the liveries with my shifter paddles. It's not like you can't get from here to there in the game on a wheel; it's just a PITA to do so on some occasions. I was able to use the keyboard as well, I had no issues mixing and matching the return and escape buttons into the wheel button mix at first. Once I got the hang of all the buttons the keyboard was able to be set aside. I shouldn't have to work so hard to get through a menu, mouse support should be like 2 or 3 on the list of things to fix/improve/implement. It's a PC game, it needs PC control.The environment and atmosphere are done very well. Track side is lively enough yet not overbearing or intrusive. The graphics are dated but look just fine in play mode as I flail the wheel in 3rd hanging on for all I've got. Replays don't look quite as good, but are more than passable for me. I think they hired GT5 to make a guest appearance or something. While the surroundings look very good, the cars are aliased and a bit blocky and the damage model looks to be lifted straight from Kaz' special vault. Gotta love elongated oval lights that stretch like silly putty after an incident...Speaking of damage... The "get some and have to repair it" side is perfectly done. It's not a stretch to have to swap tires, re-balance them or replace a cracked/stressed/bent rim. Clogged filters, oil changes, damage to the body and cooling systems or brakes that took a beating on a particularly bad section. All of this is there in a simple slider system. You repair them with Time, allotting what you can to whatever you want to fix. It all works well enough, isn't overly complicated, calls for some strategic decision making and acts as a wear and tear factor in addition to damage. At the end of a stage, money is subtracted from your winnings to bring the car back up to snuff for the next event. Again, a simple solution that's just enough to make for some nice extra immersion.I like how the crew expands and affects the car under you, just enough to give the "elite team" feel without going overboard. Throw in the simplified team management of hiring engineers and there is enough to give the game that little bit of extra depth. It's not like the game will collapse into a black hole without these features, but to me they are just enough to complete the whole Driver-Team-Race Day feel into a nice cohesive package that really helps establish immersion before I ever hit the track.I love the fact you can screw up. Royally. Like blow an entire stage or event due to being daft at the controls. In most minor incidents you can recover with a time penalty, a slight of hand that mimics the fans rolling you over or pushing you back to the stage so you can continue. However there are times when as a driver you really mess up and go too far off or do too much damage to continue. In those cases that's it, you're done. I'm glad the game has the stones to flirt with this kind of stark reality, I've already seen too many cries of take it out. I hope they don't. Really makes me appreciate the times when I get it right, and let's face it; nothing makes you learn how to drive better and use your head more than a couple DNFs.The drive physics feel very good, they equate quite well to my real life experiences in similar conditions. The FFB gives me enough but could do so much more in this area, the information is somewhere between basic and detailed once the wheel is tweaked. I don't find issue with the braking, in a straight line with a vehicle specifically equipped for the conditions it's not surprising to see the level of performance the game gives. Where I look is when the car is out of shape and you ask it to do something it shouldn't be able to do. The first time you try to stomp the pedal while being slightly sideways and find it only makes you go more sideways and you find the road really isn't as wide as it looks and that trees and gravity are not your friends it begins to sink in that maybe the brakes aren't as good as you thought. I find the throttle control is very good, very much fun. Ripping the hairpins with the e-brake and powering out is a blast, feathering the throttle for that last bit of speed as you bob and weave and hang on is quite satisfying. The car hangs on quite well, at least as long as you are on the course.There is one behavior I find peculiar, the car tends to bog down when no throttle is applied a bit too generously. In heavy mud, heavy snow or deep gravel I can see it, on ice or tarmac..? Not so much. The only thing I can think of that would cause this behavior is a ton of drive line drag, something that would be in play with short, tight gearing. That said, as much as I like that I can rely on this "feature" it seems a bit over done. I think this plays into the too much grip or braking too good feeling as well.The co driver works fine for me, and it's really well done. I love it when I get into fast or tight sections and I can get him to stutter or get a bit confused. Don't know if it's intentional or if the game is just trying to cue up files for the next corners, but hearing him fumble about just adds that little extra edge of urgency and immersion for me. I hope it stays that way.Over all the game is a bucket load of fun. I'm not constantly harassed by console energy drift garbage, the atmosphere and the drive are really well done, the stages are great including the almighty DNF for being an NDMF. (...non driving mother fill in the blank...) It's already a great run out of the gate for fun mixed with a good dose of realism. Yeah it has it's issues, but what game doesn't..? And they are only going to add more to it to boot. Worth the money already.If you're on the fence about it, all you'll get are splinters in your butt squirming around the should I or shouldn't I. Just take into account the limitations of presets for wheels and the menus being button and keyboard before you jump. Once past that bit of reliving the 90's there's nothing but merciless fun to be had.Cheers..!

content:
Posted: June 28, 2015
Early Access Review
								I have always loved racing games, and the original Colin McRae Rally was one of my absolute favorites. This is the first game since the original that has given me the same thrill of pure rally racing. I have played and enjoyed all of the Dirt games, but I always prefer pure rally, and have been hankering for a game that captures the spirit. Codemasters have finally delivered the absolute perfect rally game. It wasn't easy to get in to, but it certainly rewards patience and determination. I haven't mastered it yet, but I want to reset my career and start again, maybe placing better each time. Not many games deserve replay, but this one definitely does. I can't wait to see what the finished product looks like. The graphics are the most realistic I have ever seen. Can you tell how much I loved this game?

												I'm not one to be "driven" to review games unless I disliked it; but in this case I have to say something as I spend hours on Racing titles of all genres and platforms:I haven't been this impressed and excited by a new racing game since Colin Mcrae 2 on my long dead PSX.It's a brutal hard work experience that leaves your wheel hot and your arms exhausted.A super positive return to serious Rallying from Codemasters with no fluffy popcorn events, superfluous animations or annoying monologues from vain and expensive celebraties.Setting up your car has become a far more personal and technical task but the differences to the performance on track are distinctly noticable.I could go on but I need to go race...P.S. I'm speechless... It seems there is NO online Rallying. Just Rallycross!How... Why?

content:
Posted: November 26, 2016
												I've played a lot of racing games, from arcade to sims, and this by far feels the best in terms of physics. Don't be confused, this game will rip your heart out and stomp on it, then stick it back inside your feeble corpse and convince you it won't hurt you again...then of course it does, with one ill-timed throttle increase and a bump that sends you spinning wildly into a tree. But if you can survive the steep learning curve, you will be rewarded with the best feeling rally game ever made. From the authentic experience of a co-driver giving you turn-by-turn instructions in your ear, to carefully crafted courses, this is a beautiful game which should be enjoyed by any racing enthusiast.

content:
Posted: June 30, 2016
												DiRT Rally is what a rally game was always meant to be. It is incredibly challenging, especially if you use only a mouse and keyboard, and is unforgiving. My history in racing games started with Grand Turismo 3, on the ps2. That was considered a "racing simulator" and was challenging at the time. From there it went GT4, GT5, some DiRT 3 and a little bit of Forza. I would put DiRT Rally on par with Forza in the way the cars take damage and how that damage is felt by the player. Blow a tire and you will know it when you lose traction, power, and steering control. The different surfaces also handle differently. Snow is different than gravel and is different than ice which is different than dirt. It can take some time getting adjusted to each different road type when you are going from one event to the next. The games progression is very rewarding, you have to learn the cars you drive in order to progress at any real pace. There is also a nice progression for mastering a car you really like. I personally enjoy the Mini, which is a very low "tier" car, but I am able to progress with that car and go to larger and larger championships. I would recommend this game to anyone who is very into rally racing or racing in general. It is not for those enjoy arcade or need for speed type racing games. This would be a perfect game however if you are looking to move on from that genre. Can be frustrating at times but also incredibly rewarding.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2015
Early Access Review
								DiRT was a great game; variety, depth, and style combined to deliver one of the best racing titles in memory. The series took a step away from simulation with DiRT 2, using a more arcade-y physics package, gimmicky races and locations, and tacky cameos from Pastrana and Block. DiRT 3 and Showdown...more of the same, if not even worse.Finally, Codemasters brings us back to the glory days, giving us a rally game worth playing. No nonsense, unforgiving (to a fault at points, and yes, Wales, I'm speaking of you), visually impressive, and just plain fun. I've barely gotten into the game, yet I've found myself with white knuckles multiple times in a Mini with barely 100 horsepower. Looking forward to seeing the finished product.

content:
Posted: August 4, 2015
Early Access Review
Introduction:Overall/So far (8/4/15) this is a very solid game for PC racing fans. Keep in mind that this is a racing sim not just some fun casual racing game. If you're expecting an expansion of the DiRT series like 2 & 3 it's a very different game. Pros:Amazing graphicsRealistic PhysicsGreat Car soundsVery few bugs for Early AccessGood selection of carsGreat tracksOptimized quite wellAbility for masteryCons:Some times it's too realistic which is difficultWhen playing you can't chill and race, too realistic and AI is too good for that Very little car options (maybe because of early access..?)Restarting/Recovering is quite depriving and criplingRecording your gameplay is quite bad for performance (maybe just me)Conclusion:I would definatly recommend this since it isn't expensive and they are always adding free content throughout development. If you enjoy sim racing and rally/offroad racing this game will entertain you.For more reviews check out  Original Curators Group

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 2, 2015
Early Access Review
								My take on Dirt Rally (pre order release): Two words or less: Merciless Fun.The good, the bad, the ugly and the indifferent:Can't speak to controller land, I don't equate controller and SIM at all; it's like an oxymoron. That said, it's not really a SIM, it's a very serious game with some decent underpinnings and good enough visuals to get the job done. Be prepared to play with the FFB settings to get rid of the muddled center and spring action and tweak the rest of it to get what you want. Well at least get it close enough... Once tweaked the FFB is as passable as AC or Race Room; canned as the day is long but giving the appropriate info. This is with  the base Fanatec "4za" wheel with an Elite pedal set, other wheels will vary.One thing I lament right off the rip is the fact the wheel button/pedal schemes are cast in cement. It's 2015 not 1995... They say they're going to address this for different wheels which is great news, however I have to wonder if that will include telling the game I want to use a particular pedal or button for something regardless of input device. I am really hoping they get beyond the control schema looking at me stupid with a face full of "you want teh clutch pedal to do what..?" (...a clutch pedal that isn't usable in my pedal set ATM to boot, again something they purpose to fix...) The flexibility to add stand alone shifters and e-brakes for custom cockpits will go a long way towards immersion and aren't something I'd consider optional in this day and age, it would be a detriment to the title to leave this kind of thing out again.While we're weeping and wailing and gnashing teeth, the menu still being straight out of console land for a PC title is a bit bonehead classification worthy. You'll need to drag out your wheel manual and note what buttons are what numbers. Once I figured out where the buttons were it was navigable, I could even change the liveries with my shifter paddles. It's not like you can't get from here to there in the game on a wheel; it's just a PITA to do so on some occasions. I was able to use the keyboard as well, I had no issues mixing and matching the return and escape buttons into the wheel button mix at first. Once I got the hang of all the buttons the keyboard was able to be set aside. I shouldn't have to work so hard to get through a menu, mouse support should be like 2 or 3 on the list of things to fix/improve/implement. It's a PC game, it needs PC control.The environment and atmosphere are done very well. Track side is lively enough yet not overbearing or intrusive. The graphics are dated but look just fine in play mode as I flail the wheel in 3rd hanging on for all I've got. Replays don't look quite as good, but are more than passable for me. I think they hired GT5 to make a guest appearance or something. While the surroundings look very good, the cars are aliased and a bit blocky and the damage model looks to be lifted straight from Kaz' special vault. Gotta love elongated oval lights that stretch like silly putty after an incident...Speaking of damage... The "get some and have to repair it" side is perfectly done. It's not a stretch to have to swap tires, re-balance them or replace a cracked/stressed/bent rim. Clogged filters, oil changes, damage to the body and cooling systems or brakes that took a beating on a particularly bad section. All of this is there in a simple slider system. You repair them with Time, allotting what you can to whatever you want to fix. It all works well enough, isn't overly complicated, calls for some strategic decision making and acts as a wear and tear factor in addition to damage. At the end of a stage, money is subtracted from your winnings to bring the car back up to snuff for the next event. Again, a simple solution that's just enough to make for some nice extra immersion.I like how the crew expands and affects the car under you, just enough to give the "elite team" feel without going overboard. Throw in the simplified team management of hiring engineers and there is enough to give the game that little bit of extra depth. It's not like the game will collapse into a black hole without these features, but to me they are just enough to complete the whole Driver-Team-Race Day feel into a nice cohesive package that really helps establish immersion before I ever hit the track.I love the fact you can screw up. Royally. Like blow an entire stage or event due to being daft at the controls. In most minor incidents you can recover with a time penalty, a slight of hand that mimics the fans rolling you over or pushing you back to the stage so you can continue. However there are times when as a driver you really mess up and go too far off or do too much damage to continue. In those cases that's it, you're done. I'm glad the game has the stones to flirt with this kind of stark reality, I've already seen too many cries of take it out. I hope they don't. Really makes me appreciate the times when I get it right, and let's face it; nothing makes you learn how to drive better and use your head more than a couple DNFs.The drive physics feel very good, they equate quite well to my real life experiences in similar conditions. The FFB gives me enough but could do so much more in this area, the information is somewhere between basic and detailed once the wheel is tweaked. I don't find issue with the braking, in a straight line with a vehicle specifically equipped for the conditions it's not surprising to see the level of performance the game gives. Where I look is when the car is out of shape and you ask it to do something it shouldn't be able to do. The first time you try to stomp the pedal while being slightly sideways and find it only makes you go more sideways and you find the road really isn't as wide as it looks and that trees and gravity are not your friends it begins to sink in that maybe the brakes aren't as good as you thought. I find the throttle control is very good, very much fun. Ripping the hairpins with the e-brake and powering out is a blast, feathering the throttle for that last bit of speed as you bob and weave and hang on is quite satisfying. The car hangs on quite well, at least as long as you are on the course.There is one behavior I find peculiar, the car tends to bog down when no throttle is applied a bit too generously. In heavy mud, heavy snow or deep gravel I can see it, on ice or tarmac..? Not so much. The only thing I can think of that would cause this behavior is a ton of drive line drag, something that would be in play with short, tight gearing. That said, as much as I like that I can rely on this "feature" it seems a bit over done. I think this plays into the too much grip or braking too good feeling as well.The co driver works fine for me, and it's really well done. I love it when I get into fast or tight sections and I can get him to stutter or get a bit confused. Don't know if it's intentional or if the game is just trying to cue up files for the next corners, but hearing him fumble about just adds that little extra edge of urgency and immersion for me. I hope it stays that way.Over all the game is a bucket load of fun. I'm not constantly harassed by console energy drift garbage, the atmosphere and the drive are really well done, the stages are great including the almighty DNF for being an NDMF. (...non driving mother fill in the blank...) It's already a great run out of the gate for fun mixed with a good dose of realism. Yeah it has it's issues, but what game doesn't..? And they are only going to add more to it to boot. Worth the money already.If you're on the fence about it, all you'll get are splinters in your butt squirming around the should I or shouldn't I. Just take into account the limitations of presets for wheels and the menus being button and keyboard before you jump. Once past that bit of reliving the 90's there's nothing but merciless fun to be had.Cheers..!

content:
Posted: May 1, 2015
Early Access Review
								I've played DiRT Rally for a couple of hours now and I've got to say that as a rally racing simulator, it is a vast improvement over the previous installments in the DiRT franchise. If you just casually played DiRT 2, 3, or Showdown, this probably isn't the arcade racer you are looking for. This is a legitimate Rally Sim. The career mode is much improved with a full team and realistic car damage.I'm having a blast and it's only been in Early Access for a week now. I can't wait to see what else Codemasters brings to this game.

Early Access Review
								This game is such a game changer for rally games I don't even know where to start.Graphics; If you have played DiRT 3, you will notice a distinct difference to begin with, but I found that actually it makes DiRT 3 look less realistic than I thought it was, this game looks real - if you have enough time to look at the scenery that is.Gameplay; This game is not for the arcade racer. There are plenty of assists, but I always pride myself on turning them all off. I did so for DiRT 3 and was still finding it quite easy. In this game the cars have real traction issues, grip is not consistent on surfaces and cars twitch at speed, much like real life. On gravel and snow with 0 ABS you have to use engine braking to burn speed coupled with braking otherwise you lock up and goodbye to your stage time. The tracks are long and different, even at alpha stage. It takes some time to get used to, but it is the first time I have geniunely smiled from ear to ear after coming second in a stage even though I was 10 seconds off the top spot.AI; The AI aren't super difficult, and they have bad runs sometimes, which keeps it interesting. The co driver is excellent and you have to really concentrate, but it pays off and is much more specific than DiRT 3.Audio; The cars sound raw, the sounds of the track help you decide how to tackle corners with changes in gravel density and ice patches. The co driver sounds shaky, as if he were in a rally car and gets nervous in places as his pace notes speed up.There aren't millions of cars, or hundreds of tracks but it doesn't matter. I use an Xbox 360 controller and I would say you should at least have one or a wheel for this but it is so worth it. I used to play Colin McRae Rally on PC and PS1 so much and DiRT 3 didn't feel like those games. This game goes back to what it is all aboutl; Serious Rallying. God I love this game and Codemasters. <3

They are so good that you could actually mistake a screenshot for a real picture.Great physics, and car handling is on point.A system in which you select and hire members for your rally team, can upgrade and buy new cars, and in between rally stages, have to decide which parts of the car you want to repair, to fit within the time limit.You can customise EVERYTHING in the car to fit the racing conditions, and even load configurations from the workshop.If you are used to playing DiRT 3 or Showdown, the handling, and the speed at which you have to travel will be hard to get used to at first, but when you get it right, and finally smash a time on a rally track, or come first in rallycross, the feeling is amazing.This game brings back memories of the old Colin McRae games, before they absolutely ruined the series with DiRT 3 and Showdown.I could not recommend this game more. Buy it if it's on sale. Buy it if it's not on sale. Buy it if the price increases to £50. You will not be disappointed.Points to consider:No gymkhana.No Ken Block.Not arcadey.No rewinds.No Ken Block.No gymkhana.Just rally in its purest form.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 12, 2016
												After first 2 hours of game play i was wondering, "what's with the difficulty?!" Difficulty at first felt really brutal and i kept losing and losing and the time gap just kept growing but i decided to keep trying and eventually i started winning championships, which brings the difficulty up for the next championship. Current trend for game difficulties seems to be very casual so i have got bored with many games so i really appreciate this system where i have to get gradually better until i start winning and at that point game reacts and increases the difficulty automatically so it keeps me alert and keeps the game challenging. This difficulty also means that this game is not for casual friday nights with few beers because of the concentration that is required to play the game, though we can always argue about this depending of how good the player is with driving games and which type of peripherals are used to play. (Game pad or proper steering wheel with pedals and so on...)I've been playing with xbox 360 controller and i've had all the assists off except automatic gear change. Because of the realistic car handling and so on i think a proper steering wheel and pedals would do more justice to the game simply because real rally cars aren't driven using xbox360 controllers not to mention using clutch and chaning gears on a controller, which feels a bit ridiculous. Game pad can be customised in game to be more or less sensitive to meet your preferation.After all this has been a very good game and good change after playing all these RPGs with swords and shields. Money well spent.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 30, 2016
												DiRT Rally is what a rally game was always meant to be. It is incredibly challenging, especially if you use only a mouse and keyboard, and is unforgiving. My history in racing games started with Grand Turismo 3, on the ps2. That was considered a "racing simulator" and was challenging at the time. From there it went GT4, GT5, some DiRT 3 and a little bit of Forza. I would put DiRT Rally on par with Forza in the way the cars take damage and how that damage is felt by the player. Blow a tire and you will know it when you lose traction, power, and steering control. The different surfaces also handle differently. Snow is different than gravel and is different than ice which is different than dirt. It can take some time getting adjusted to each different road type when you are going from one event to the next. The games progression is very rewarding, you have to learn the cars you drive in order to progress at any real pace. There is also a nice progression for mastering a car you really like. I personally enjoy the Mini, which is a very low "tier" car, but I am able to progress with that car and go to larger and larger championships. I would recommend this game to anyone who is very into rally racing or racing in general. It is not for those enjoy arcade or need for speed type racing games. This would be a perfect game however if you are looking to move on from that genre. Can be frustrating at times but also incredibly rewarding.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 4, 2015
Early Access Review
								I've always loved rallying. Through the butt-clenching hairpin turns on a track barely wider than your car, or the long stretches of track with trees on one side and a cliff edge on the other truly make rally racing an unique discipline. When Colin McRae's DiRT landed I was thrilled. A bit arcade-y, but it was an extremely fun game and was chock full of rallying goodies.  Unfortunately, the series took a downward spiral of depression, and started gaining unnecessary weight through the use of Ken Block, gymkhana, and developed diabetes from a general "Dude-bro" attitude to the sport.Thankfully, Codemasters released DiRT Rally. DiRT Rally cuts off all that extra and unnecessary weight, and throws everything wrong with DiRT 2, DiRT 3 and DiRT Showdown out the window and focuses on pure rallying with no extra B.S.If you want Gymkhana, Ken Block, Explosions, Fireworks, Rewinds, then this game is not for you.If you want just rallying; rallying in it's purest form from the likes that we haven't seen since the glory days of Richard Burn's Rally, then I think you will enjoy this game.While I wouldn't say DiRT Rally is the be-all-end-all of simulation Rally (I'd say it's more Simcade) it's still a very thought out game. It is by no means at all easy to drive these beasts on the gravel. You WILL crash. A lot.Another thing to keep in mind, the game is Early Access. There IS a chance that the game will fail to deliver. However, it seems Codemasters has a very good, thorough plan set for the next couple of months (Pikes Peak and Rallycross soon!)But the game is already fleshed out pretty well, with a championship mode and an interesting multiplayer function called "Leagues" where friends can race against each other to set the best times in multiple events.Here's hoping Codemasters stays faithful to the old fans of rallying.  I look forward to seeing what comes of DiRT Rally in the future.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 17, 2015
												Wow, they really gave us what we asked for! And then some!  Each update really provides more detail, tracks, cars, physics, and features.  I can already tell this game will keep every one captivated for hours, whether it's trying all the different cars, dialing the car in for the perfect stage, crafting a great team, or just hopping into a 4WD monster and flooring it.Great physics- being comparred to some of the best rally games of all timeLooks amazingIt's hard! Get to work and get better!UPDATE 12/7/15Many more hours into game - Still blown away every bit of content that has been released has been top notch, and uncompromising. There are so many elements to this game that make it immersive, from learing each car and class, hiring your crew chief and crew machanics, dynamic real world elements in each track.   To keep the rest of this simple, there are plenty of classes to master and cars to unlock to keep you busy, enough track and condition combos that "grinding" to get money doesn't feel boring.  The gameplay experience is awesome, beautiful game, great physics, awesome car and suspension models.  Online works well, not great yet, but I'm sure now that it's offically released it will only grow.   There is already a strong community behind this game, come join the fun!

content:
Posted: December 30, 2016
												This game is absolutely fantastic, certainly the most fun I've ever had in a racing game. There is a broad range of cars, and customization for tuning each vehicle. The courses, detail to realism, vehicle performance, and overall feeling is very well done. I spent my time in my first races yelling in frustration at the game due to difficulty, this enticed me to strive for improvement, which forces you to maintain complete focus of everything you are doing. As you improve after each race, it makes the challenge completely rewarding, and the true fun begins. Most racing games I have played are beautifully done in many ways although; I believe lack the challenge that is necessary to continue coming back. Dirt Rally, from my experience is the complete opposite of a typical, 'hold your hand', racing game. If you love racing games/simulators with a true challenge, this game is most certainly for you. *I would also suggest purchasing a wheel and pedals if you do not own one, it is not the same without (in my opinion).

content:

Early Access Review
								Firstly do not expect to pick up this game and win right away...it's very unlikely! The game feels unforgiving at first but patience and practice begin to pay off after just a couple of hours. The game is a superb blitz through Wales/Greece/Monte Carlo (at the moment) with Rally car through the ages. It's early access and more stages and hillclimbs are to come but there different styles and eras of cars keep you on your toes.One thing to do for sure is to make use of the shakedowns where possible to fine tune the set up of your car and understand the feel of the surface.I have been using Xbox controller for windows and have found this to be pretty decent although I imagine a wheel and pedal set up would give such a better feel.Although early access this is already shaping up to be a classic and one of the best Rally games ever. Daily, weekly and monthly online challenges enable you to challenge yourself against the world which keeps things fresh and adds some further excitment.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 6, 2015
Early Access Review
								This review covers my impression based on the quite extensive playing of the game I've had thus far. It is on early access and a lot may, and hopefully will change until the final release. Pros:- Reallism. The game feels realistic and the difficulty is punishing to mistakes and rewarding when you complete a stage well. Its on the simulator spectrum and I like it. - Sound. The engine sounds are amazing and other sound the ones the brakes makes as they are starting to wear brings a great immersion. - Stage design, Most stages are really nice and have a well balanced blend of fast and curvy parts.- Overall experience. The game has a great potential to become a fantastic, realistic rally game. Cons. - Controls. A lot needs to be done to steering wheels and analog input. This is something the developers are working on but at present the game might be unplayable to you. I had to alter the settings text file to get a somewhat good input from my steering wheel. - Menus. The menus are simplistic and ugly. They also have a very arcady feel that doesn't go very well with the game. The menu music is also like something you'd find in an arcade hall racing game. yuck! - Standardization of "long" and "sprint" stages. The game has only two types of track lengths, one with 4 checkpoints and one with 8. Why? It puts the game in the arcade camp again and feels utterly unnecessary. - Indecision. In my experience the game both wants to promote a gamestyle in which you play with your mistakes and in which replay is punished, but it also promotes memorization of stages.  In the campaign mode you are punished for restarting a stage and thus you are supposed to drive as fast as you can but also play safe because mistakes are unforgiving. In pretty much every stage however there are parts that you can't get right by just following the notes. A corner right after a jump, a grade 4 corner that you pretty much need to bring the car to a stand still to pass right when you normally pass those corners at some speed and so on...I dont know it its a concious design choice or not but atleast I feel that I have no chance what so ever to do a good time on a stage without having driven it atleast two or three times previously. There is always that corner where you follow the notes and flies right of the road because the corner is not what the notes prepared you for.- Car settings. If you are really hardcore I bet the settings are really nice. For me, I'd like some kind of profile-system to be implemented. Overall though. I really, really like the game and I hope the final product turns out nice. I heartily recommend it to everyone that likes rally!

Early Access Review
								Beautiful graphics, really steep learning curve and limited choices of races and cars in the beginning. You have to be top 3 to advance to a new tier of cars and racing tracks. I've been playing for a little over 10 hours and I'm still stuck on the same circuit race event, same tracks, same two cars.  By the way, if you run through a barrier wall mid game and fall to your doom over a mountainside, there is no reset button to redo that race. You are starting from the beginning of a 12 race curcuit. Very aggrevating and it's one of the major gripes I have with the game. You have to literally improve quickly or suck and finish 12 races in 4th position just a hair shy of having enough to advance to another racing divison with better cars and more tracks.I would NOT recommend this game to casual racers that thrive on NFS and other less realistic racing games of the sort.  I almost gave this a negative review if it werent for the beautiful graphics and avoiding the hate I would get from all the dirt-rally-heads that wet themselves playing this.

content:
Posted: January 6, 2016
												DiRT 2 was what I have played the most out of the DiRT Franchise. Even back from its initial release date in September 2009, the physics of the game were pretty impressive for the "technology of its time." The way the suspenion and tires handle from different terrains along with the style of driving you're using, the game really adapts to pretty much exactly how you want to drive. Now, DiRT Rally is utterly amazing. The physics have improved astronomically and are so close to really life it's not even funny. Again, the DiRT Franchise continues to be the best rally racing game I could play. All the way back from the original DiRT, I can't stop playing these games! I need to get use of my controller back!

												Wow, they really gave us what we asked for! And then some!  Each update really provides more detail, tracks, cars, physics, and features. Online works well, not great yet, but I'm sure now that it's offically released it will only grow.   There is already a strong community behind this game, come join the fun!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 5, 2016
												I wholeheartedly recommend DiRT Rally. However, there's a few things you should know if you're considering buying the game:It's brutal and unforgiving. This is not Forza -  if you crash your car so badly that you can't get back on the track, you get a hefty time penalty and some considerable repair bills to boot. If you mess up, the game will punish you.It's not really a game, either. This, friends, is a simulator. It's not branded like one, but it is one. If you want a game that'll let you be stupid and do ridiculous slides around corners, defying every law of physics ever written, then go play Project CARS or Assetto Corsa or something. If you want something that is about as true to life as a game can get, this is the game for you.Speaking of true to life, this game absolutely is. Handling the cars, despite being absolutely not cartoony, feels real. They feel weighty and if you try to do something stupid around a corner, you can feel the cars fight it. Especially if you're using a controller or wheel, which I would seriously recommend.The graphics and SFX don't detract from the atmosphere either. The game looks and sounds fantastic.All in all, this game is absolutely not for everyone. An acquired taste, I'd call it. If you want something you can hop onto every once in a while and burn some rubber doing doughnuts and drifts, look elsewhere. If, however, you want a gritty, true-to-life rallycross simulator with excellent graphics and sound design that's so immersive you can actually smell the petrolium fumes, DiRT is your game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 4, 2015
												First review Good to get away from the arcade type of rally that the previous Dirt games are and to get back to the gritty rally sim that this developer is renowned for creating. Update 05/08/2015A few months after release Codemasters have supported the games development by making improvements and making fixes. They have also included a ton of new content such as WRC FIA Rally Cross and Hill Climb and included the relavent rally car classes with the events.Dirt Rally is shaping up to be codemasters best rally game to dateUpdate 17/11/15As we get closer to the release of the game and the full RRP in December all i can say is buy the game now. The game has come a long way since it's ential early access release back in April of 2015. Codemasters have supported it's early access phase on Steam and have provided regular updates in the form of tweaks and game content. I find the online daily, weekly and monthly events worth while doing because you can see how you improve with time by using the world leaderboards as with these events you only have one shot to get over the finish line and provide your best time. Dirt Rally has also had input from professional WRC drivers to help with the authenticity of the car handling and rally stages which has certainly helped with how good this game has become. Go on Youtube their are videos of the drivers playing the game.   Their is no doubt about it apart from the co-driver that needs more tweaking forget all other rally games that are available on the market. Dirt Rally is the best and most realistic Rally sim that is available. If you are a fan of rallying and of the FIA WRC this game is for you. Final Release update 8th April 2016 I have seen this game be develop since it's day one launch into early access Dirt Rally was great then but light on content and the cars had a few balancing issues but over the past year they have provided content updates such as new cars, game modes, and system stability updates. At this moment in time i am enjoying Rallycross the most can't say why but i am. the final version of the game is supurb it is no longer light on content and the stability for pc is amazing and graphical wise in 1440p the game is beautiful it plays like a dream. I said it not long after Dirt Rally was released that it was shaping up to be Codemasters best rally game and it has this is the best rally game/simulater that i have played since Colin Mcrae back on PS1. This game is hard and unforgiving but very rewarding when you win. Put all other rally games down yes im thinking Sabastion Loeb Rally, WRC 2015 this is the only rally game you need. Codemasters you have done right by your fans keep up the good work, Excellent job with DIrt Rally you have really given what your fans were asking for :)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 7, 2016
												This game is a rally fans dream come true.  they completely nailed the sound of the crackling exaust, the whine of the straight cut gears.  The game is just an absolute treat to all the senses. i have a medium powered rig but the game seems very well optimized for pc gaming, im able to max out nearly everything besides shadows and anti aliasing without much framerate drop at all. I find myself completely ignoring the campaign simply because i love hopping around all the rallies and trying all the different cars.  which brings me to my only gripe about this game.  it feels a little lacking in the way of content.  I know its a rally only game im not expecting a 200+ roster of cars.  But it seems to be completely missing some no brainer cars, for example the legendary celica gt four awd is missing. every single generation is absent.  the subaru legacy and mitsubishi galant vr4 were a few others i was really hoping to see. hell they have a whole class listed as 1960's rally, and it only has one car in it.  the game just seems incomplete in the way of a car roster.  other environments like desert, or more urban tracks would have been nice too with some rallies in africa or north america as a few examples.  Id recommend waiting til a sale and picking it up, for 30 dollars i am completely satisfied with my purchase, it is an amazing rally simulator that has gameplay that will not dissapoint.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 29, 2016
												DiRT Rally is a great game. If you're someone who likes to get behind the wheel and just drive for hours upon end with minimal interuption, this game is for you. First off, the game is pretty difficult, which also makes it realistic. When I first started out, I could hardly even drive in a straight line. Then I learned about throttle management. After a couple hours, I thought I had gotten it down. Then, I realized all of the cars had different driving styles. The problem was that I had been driving the same car the whole time, so I wasn't used to the other ones. So, it'll take a while to get used to every car you are driving, but damn it's so much fun.I'm not exactly sure, but I think the career mode is automatically set on the hardest difficulty (don't quote me on that, I just don't remember having the option to choose a difficulty). I'm not the best at the game, nor am I trying to brag, but I hit some corners perfectly and nail multiple sections in Rally, but I still end up 2nd every time and about 30 seconds behind the leader in total race time. The career mode is indeed quite tough and if you've never played a rally game before, it will take some getting used to a British guy shouting in your ear. But I promise, you will learn to love him because he will be your savior. Just listen to what he says and you won't regret it! The rallycross is probably my favorite part of this game. The points system is great and the final race always gives a real challenge. Though, some tracks feel too easy to win at once you've mastered them, even with the AI on Very Hard. The Hillclimb championship isn't my favorite, but I can see how it could be fun to people that want a real challenge. The British guy isn't screaming into your ear for this one, so you are on your own trying to master the course. Which is probably why there is currently only one track in this game mode.I wouldn't recommend using a keyboard for this game. It feels clunky and most keyboards aren't pressure sensitive which makes throttle management a real pain in the neck. I would recomend either a controller or wheel if you have the money/interest for racing games. The controller suits me just fine and it's also worth messing with the sensitivity options to get it to match your driving style. I don't have the money or interest to buy a wheel for the only racing I have (besides DiRT 3 for the 360), but I've heard the force feedback can be customized and lots of racing wheels are supported.PROS:-Decent amount of content (Lots of cars, lacking a bit on the amount of rallycross tracks I think)-Lovely Environments-Extremely realistic & hardcore (Which is more fun than it sounds)-Nearly perfect car physics simulation on all terrain (I've never felt a racing game quite like it)-Accurate & advanced car tuning that allows you to correct the car where you feel it's lacking (Practice, practice, practice so you can tune it how you want)-Nice and simple career mode that I can see being expanded upon in the future-Even if you suck at racing games, it's still pretty fun. My friend is terrible at racing games but he loves DiRT because of the crashes and pure destruction of the car (Especially in the cockpit view)-The sound design of this game is phonomenal and really adds to the immersion & experience-They are always adding more and more to the base gameCONS:-AI needs a lot of work. Sometimes, they won't even acknoledge your existance and will just plow through you without letting go of the gas. On the Norway rallycross track, watch out for the AI taking the joker lap because if you get in their way, they will total you (I'm not kidding). I got pretty mad because this happened to me almost every time I raced there. I really hope they fix this soon.-Some tiny objects, like bushes, that look like you can plow through them are actually made of solid adamantium and cannot be moved. There is a slight issue on the hitboxes of these objects too. Even if you scrape them, your car has a chance to tailwhip and spin or flip completely. It doesn't really matter how fast you are going either.-Even though the career mode is simple, it can feel a little too minimal at times. I'd like to be able to go into the garage and upgrade specific things or give my car a simple paint, graphic, sponsor and number. I can see this being something the developers are well aware of and would probably want to be in the game eventually, but I understand that the focus of the game is the driving experience over the cosmetics.This game is amazing. It does what it's supposed to do and does it very well. The other reviews are true, it IS the "Dark Souls" of racing, but if you give it time and patience, I promise you will have lots of fun. I'm pretty picky when it comes to racing games and I can easily say that this is the best racing game I've ever played!9/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 29, 2016
												A WORTHY INVESTMENT!You might be wondering...How can you call a video game an investment?Well you can only do so when speaking in regard to games of this caliber! Rally is a great game to begin with, but it is also evolving and new content is being added along with beneficial updates. It is not a product that has been haphazardly slapped together and left to sit in the market unattended to. When playing Dirt Ralley, and when involving yourself with the community you feel apart of a ongoing project to acheive excellence. Especially during the testing period of this game, I felt as though I played a part in making the game what it is by being ASKED for my input as a player. Today still, I feel as though the creators of DIRT put a special interest in the feedback of the players and thus this game's community and its development still thrives.Very few games can constitute as a rewarding investment. But in my opinion I feel you will enjoy DIRT: Rally now and well into the future as improvements are continually being made and content is still being added!If you're simply a racer at heart, then you can't ask for a better game! Though, not everyone will enjoy following strict paths and being TOLD where to go and when in order to get a good lap time. Rally is not necessarily for the faint of heart, even so you will find that the challenge and danger present alone in traversing hazardous off-road terrains will immediately suck you in!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 29, 2016
												The last racing games I played "seriously" were Gran Turismo and Colin McRae Rally on PS1 in like 98. I don't have a driver's license. I don't watch Rally events and couldn't give a toss about F1 or any other racing sports. Enter Dirt Rally.When I first tried to play the game I couldn't even drive in a straight line for very long before spectacularly crashing and burning. It beat me down, forced a FWD car down my throat just after I learned how to somewhat stay on the track without spinning out of control using a RWD car. It asked me to hire engineers, the upkeep of which almost bankrupted me because of my low income due to how poorly I drove.Then, after about 10 (painful) hours, I finally drove a nice, fluid hairpin for the first time. I have high hopes that I will be able to complete a Rallycross event with a placement above 16 one day. :PI bought the game during early access and much content was added since then. I am very happy with my purchase and think it's possibly the game with the most love put into it by the developers which I have bought in the last 3 years.There are some things I don't like, namely the lack of a tutorial/practice mode (it's pretty frustrating/impractical to try and learn specific maneuvers like hairpins during actual races), co-driver calls being too early or late on some tracks (sometimes I get info so late that I at least collide with something, other times I have to remember the next 2 events in advance, which feels like having to balance an egg on your nose while you're performing surgery on someone- it's pretty annoying)- Finland is particularly atrocious for this, the career mode seems kind of pointless/grindy for♥♥♥♥♥♥drivers, and dailies/weeklies/monthlies requiring ownership of certain cars is kind of harsh on aforementioned incompetent drivers, also. Lastly, while I enjoy the idea of unlocking upgrades on your car (like weight reduction), it simply doesn't really fit a game as hardcore as Dirt Rally. If I unlock a car for a daily I have to go drive it against bots for a while before doing the daily so I can be competitive? That's rubbish.All in all, even if you're not into racing games normally, you might wanna give this a go, it's SO good (don't let my low hours fool ya). If you do normally play racing games and you don't own this yet...what is wrong with you?P.S.: Wales can still go ♥♥♥♥ itself.
